fields.intro: Good ideas for good people since 2000.

fields.body:
We've got digital marketing covered too. We can manage your social media channels, tell your story to a wider audience, generate new content ideas, and optimize your Google Grant. Just ask.

And we want our clients to see the best possible return on their investment. Close collaboration and an agile and flexible approach mean we can respond and adapt to evolving requirements as we work towards a Minimum Viable Product, without breaking the bank.

Why Torchbox? Why not?
fields.quote: We work with people who are trying to make the world a better place. People who share our values.
fields.intro:
We design and build beautiful websites for some of the world’s great universities and academic institutions, globally-renowned think tanks, fundraising charities, campaigning NGOs, research programmes, and leading membership organisations, powered by open source content management systems including Drupal and our very own Wagtail CMS.

Sometimes only a bespoke solution will do, and that's fine too. Our custom software engineering team use Django to build robust, scalable web applications for mission critical requirements such as management information, grant monitoring and reporting, as well as campaign platforms, footprint calculators and data visualisations.

It's not all or nothing either.
fields.heading: A digital agency with a difference.

fields.body:
What is Play?

This is some placeholder text. Play is a new branding for the digital marketing team to open new opportunities and impress potential clients. Currently, we have two types of clients:

  1. Sports related

  2. Third-sector/non-profits

The majority of our revenue comes from the first type of client. We want to try to build upon our successes in this sector with a coherent brand that we can take to them in pitches, meetings, conferences and shouting about our successes on social media.


The Play website is also going to double-up as a simple brand guideline template for all of our documents, including future briefs, pitches, reports and digital channels.
fields.quote: We believe the winning digital marketing is the result of compelling content and effective amplification.
fields.intro: We help clients in the sports and charity sectors make stuff happen! From developing a strategy to delivering a plan featuring content creation, search engine marketing, social media activation, email marketing and measurement reporting.
fields.heading: We are Play. We deliver content, marketing and social media solutions that help our clients achieve their objectives.

fields.content:
Digital strategy

Key to any successful strategy is understanding the objectives of our client and the needs and motivations of their users. We have an established process and tailor our approach to dovetail with the resources, knowledge and skills of our clients.

Designing the user experience

Our designers know how to make things look good, but they also know that the key to delivering lasting value is to always keep the user in mind and to create something that people will enjoy and understand.

Animation & video

Beautiful animations and vibrant videos can really help to engage your audience, communicate your message, and bring your website to life.

Drupal development

Powerful, flexible and scalable, Drupal is the best open source CMS with a great worldwide developer community. It's the right choice for us, and the right choice for our clients.

Custom software development

We can build pretty much anything you want. We'll always try to avoid reinventing the wheel, but sometimes only a custom application will suffice. Our software engineers have the skills and experience to tackle the most complex of projects.

Google Grant management

Google gives substantial grants to eligible charities for AdWords advertising. We help our clients understand and make the most of their Google Grants, enabling them to promote their website as effectively as possible.

Social media management

Social media is a powerful way for organisations to meet business goals, expand their influence and engage directly with audiences. We love helping our clients enhance their social media presence.

Search engine optimisation

We believe in helping organisations get the most out of their websites. Our SEO projects are designed to ensure that your website appeals to your supporters and to search engines in equal measure. In doing so, we can help you reach new supporters, donors, fundraisers, journalists and more.

fields.body:
Taming the beast

Google Analytics is a powerful tool, but with power comes (sometimes bewildering) complexity. The best way to deal with this is to think about the questions that you want answered before logging into Analytics - so below I try to phrase the questions I want to answer (yours will almost certainly be different).

Most of what I talk about below involves using segments; these are my preferred way of slicing and dicing Analytics data into more insightful chunks. If you've not done this before (or haven't used the new interface for segments), there are many blog posts to help you out - here’s Justin Cutroni’s from last year. Don’t forget that stacking multiple segments allows comparison between them; if you don’t want to compare between segments then use the “All Visits” segment to compare your segment with all site traffic.

1. New visitors

We spend a lot of time optimising home pages to provide an excellent means of showing all that a site has to offer, when often people arrive elsewhere from a search. For many organisations new visitors are particularly important (are they signed up to email? / my latest campaign? / etc.), so knowing where they land is vital. The question I’m interested in is: “What pages are visitors new to the site landing on?” Analytics provides a built-in segment for new visitors, so fire it up. Here it is favourited in the segments drop-down:

New users segment in Google Analytics - screengrab

Now take a look at landing pages (Behaviour > Site Content > Landing Pages). Ensure that any well-visited ones have the appropriate navigation and retention features.


2. Mobile

Understanding the journeys made by users on mobile / tablet is now very important - and vital if you’ve not yet optimised the site.

The question I’m interested in is quite wide: “Are mobile / tablet users coming to the site for different reasons than desktop, and what pages are they looking at?”

First up, take a look at your overall mobile traffic - nothing complex here, just look in Audience > Mobile > Overview. Our clients are seeing anything from 5% to 50% from mobile / tablet combined. However, a low number doesn’t mean that you don’t have to cater for mobile / tablet - it could be a worrying sign that people are bouncing from your unoptimised website.

To look at this further I use the built-in “Mobile and Tablet Traffic” segment (favourited in the screengrab below):

Mobile and tablet users segment in Google Analytics - screengrab

With this segment (and All Visits selected for comparison), I’ll take a look at landing pages (Behaviour > Site Content > Landing Pages) and see if there’s a high bounce / exit rate for the mobile / tablet segment.

I then look at the search terms people are using to get to the site, and see if these differ from the desktop segment. If it does, it might mean that people are coming to the site from mobile / tablet for a different reason, and I should look to cater for this. I then look at the landing pages for those terms, and check if these (whether optimised or not) help people on mobile / tablet complete the tasks suggested by the search terms.


3. Scroll depth

You’ll need a developer to set up the code to track scroll depth. But - if you manage a site with long pages (including your homepage), it’s essential. Once it’s working, you’ll find it as an event in Behaviour > Events.

Scroll depth chart in Google Analytics - screengrab

The question I’m interested in is this: “Are long section index pages providing a barrier for my users?”

To answer this, I create a custom segment showing scroll depth of > 75%. This will appear under the Conditions tab (click on the “Ad content” drop-down and then search for “scroll” to find it in the list). Once the segment is created, I look at exit rate from these pages (via Behaviour > Site Content > All Pages).

Any pages that have an anomalously high exit rate probably aren’t doing a good job at linking users onwards, and I can look at the in-page analytics for each of these to see why.


4. Site search

Site search (Behaviour > Site search) is a vital means for understanding not only what users are searching the site for, but the language and phrasing that they are using. It’s also often possible to pick up an anomaly between your navigation and what people are searching for - a popular search term might mean that people aren’t easily finding the link to the page(s) relating to it.

However, site search isn’t something that’s set up by default in Google Analytics. You will have to configure Analytics (and might have to get a developer to do it):-

Site search in Google Analytics settings - screengrab

Once it’s working (leave it for a month or two before analysing), check the usage; if it’s low it suggests a possible problem.

Then take a look at the search terms and look at the destination pages. Check that there are no weird mismatches.

Then view the “% Search Exits” metric. This tells you the percentage of searches in which the user left your site after searching instead of clicking any of the search results. It’s possible that your content (or search function) isn’t optimised for these searches.

5. Organic search

Sadly, “(not provided)” means that the organic search data (Acquisition > Keywords > Organic) is almost useless for providing user insight:-

(not provided) for organic keywords in Google Analytics - screengrab

However, there are ways around this. Personally, I favour the Google Webmaster Tools solution (method 4 in that link) as it also includes the clickthrough rate for particular terms, and the approximate impressions, too. This means that you can see how well or poorly you perform for particular searches, and, from a user research perspective, gives you clues to the language and wording that your users phrase their tasks with. This allows you to (manually) find the landing pages for those terms you’re not performing well for, and then optimise the pages accordingly.

Thanks for reading. For more on user experience and digital strategy, follow me on Twitter.
fields.intro: Google Analytics is a wonderful source of data about your users. However, it's all too easy to focus on the obvious rather than dig down for some real treasure. In this post, I outline five user insights from Analytics that are worth their weight in gold.
