If you only read one thing make it this great presentation by, Head of Accessibility at GDS,  Joshua Marshall:

http://digital.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/2013/09/09/talking-accessibility-at-ustwo/

Here are some of the other things things I found:

How Blind People Use Twitter & You Tube on the iPhone 4S

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c0nvdiRdehw

How blind people use the internet

http://gizmodo.com/5620079/giz-explains-how-blind-people-see-the-internet

RNIB: Design and build accessible websites

http://www.rnib.org.uk/professionals/webaccessibility/designbuild/Pages/design_build.aspx

Blind Community Fights for a More Accessible Web

http://mashable.com/2013/07/18/blind-internet/

How ARIA landmark roles help screen reader users

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IhWMou12_Vkhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IhWMou12_Vk

Make the most out of ARIA landmark roles

http://www.netmagazine.com/tutorials/make-most-aria-landmark-roles

ARIA and progressive enhancement

http://alistapart.com/article/aria-and-progressive-enhancement

Using OSX’s voiceover

https://vimeo.com/11286974

Fuck you

http://bradfrostweb.com/blog/post/fuck-you/

Skip links

http://www.nomensa.com/blog/2004/what-are-skip-links/

Technology for life

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w_EPBr_EJ9M

Sim daltonism

http://michelf.ca/projects/sim-daltonism/

BBC Accessibility

http://www.bbc.co.uk/guidelines/futuremedia/accessibility/mobile_access.shtml

---

It was nice to refresh my accessibility knowledge and I got a lot from the videos of blind and partially sighted people using the internet. Watching them use their devices and seeing the different needs and adaptations each person has helps to humanise them.
fields.intro: I’ve recently been doing some research on accessibility — in particular, designing for blind or partially sighted users. I found a bunch of useful research, articles and videos and thought it would be good to share them with you.

fields.body:
Who is it aimed at?

Wagtail is a powerful, well featured content management system, built on the popular, respected Django framework. It can power sites of any size, but it'll be particularly effective for medium to large sites with sophisticated content management requirements. Wagtail has a fantastic user interface that makes it easy and enjoyable to publish great content.


Where has it come from?

We developed Wagtail with the Royal College of Art for their new website, with the aim of releasing it as an open source project. The RCA site was launched last year and now has over 5000 pages and 8000 images in its Wagtail CMS. You can watch a video case study about the RCA implementation.

How do you feel about it?

We've been building content managed sites for 14 years. Wagtail takes the best CMS concepts, and is built using the latest web development practices. It may not yet have the wealth of plugins of some CMSs,  but it's a pleasure to extend. We love it and we are already seeing the benefits for developers and editors. The user experience is second to none.

How it's taking off?

So far, so good. We've done a very limited, developer-focused launch: a new Django conference in Cardiff and a story on Hacker News. And, in just two weeks we have:

  • 1000 stars on Github
  • other agencies interested in implementing it (watch this space)
  • pull requests from community contributors outside of Torchbox
  • people saying nice things about it
  • hosting companies supporting it
  • almost 70% test coverage
  • volunteers adding translations for the admin interface, so German and Greek editors can use it

And, look out for the relaunch of Torchbox.com on Wagtail in the next couple of weeks.

Are you still doing Drupal?

Yes. We continue to build and support Drupal sites for some fantastic organisations. Many organisations have implemented Drupal, but for those that want to look at other options, you may well find that Wagtail is the right one.
fields.intro: Big news, Torchbox have released a brand new, open source Content Management System, Wagtail.

fields.body:
The release notes for 0.2 have the details: Redis has been removed as a dependency, along with npm (used for Coffeescript and Less), and Wagtail can use its database as a simple search backend when Elasticsearch isn't available.

At the same time, we recommend that people take advantage of all the performance and functionality benefits of the optional third party services when they're using Wagtail in production. To this end, we've written one line installers for Ubuntu:

curl -O https://wagtail.io/ubuntu.sh; bash ubuntu.sh

and Debian

curl -O https://wagtail.io/debian.sh; bash debian.sh

These scripts install all the dependencies for a production-ready Wagtail site, including PostgreSQL, Redis, Elasticsearch, Nginx and uwsgi. Fire up a $5 Digital Ocean box and you can be running Wagtail five minutes later!
fields.intro: Since its launch a month ago, we've been working hard on making it easy to get started with Wagtail, our new open source CMS.

fields.body:
The image formats we’ve grown accustomed to on the web are inflexible. JPG, PNG etc aren’t human-readable, aren't editable without re-saving and they’re un-scalable without loss of quality. They’re so ubiquitous you wouldn’t think of these as limitations but if you consider modern graphic use on the web, these file formats feel increasingly restrictive and backward.

Vector-based graphics use mathematical expressions to represent position. Since an expression scales indefinitely so does a vector image, without loss of quality. Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) - a popular vector format compatible with the web - uses XML as a file format and being a human-readable language SVGs aren't the locked black box that predecessor formats are.

The need for scaling graphics is relatively new. With the release of high pixel-density display devices e.g “Retina” screens, images using raster formats can be seen to get lower resolution overnight. Try using the "zoom" function to view an old iPhone app on an iPad. Yuk!

Web designers understand this and typically solve it by creating images twice: once at double-resolution for Retina devices, another at standard resolution for everything else. Developers also have to code with two versions of each image in mind. It's not ideal.

Many website images are simple vector shapes - consider an RSS icon or a Twitter bird - and aren't much more complex than the letters of the alphabet. Fonts are vectors too so "icon fonts" were born: a font storing simple vector images instead of letters. You remember “Wingdings”, right? - same thing, except icon fonts can be created from scratch, with every “letter” of the font lovingly crafted by a designer and collated into a bespoke font for your own brand/site.

Icon fonts therefore solve the Retina issue: a font loses no detail at any pixel density. 

They also improve image production workflow too since anything we can do with real fonts on the web can be done with icon fonts too. Consider a designer creating the same image in red, blue and yellow to suit the colour themes of a site. These colour variations can now be created by a developer in a fraction of the time - literally by typing 6 characters - using the same elementary technology we’d use to make a heading font red, or a link blue - remember: they’re just fonts!

However just as you can’t shade a letter “T” with two colours simultaneously, neither can you colour an icon font. So while they have more flexible than raster images, icon fonts are still limited to monochrome.

SVG advances vector use one step further by supporting multiple colours, plus with XML as a file format the shapes and colours are all dynamically changeable with javascript and CSS. As developers are capable of making significant graphic adjustments using familiar development languages without a designer’s input, this is hugely significant.

Yet despite SVG having existed since 2001 and first supported by Konqueror (anyone remember that?) since 2004, it’s been Microsoft’s reluctance to adopt the standard till IE9’s release in 2011 that has held SVG use back.

Fortunately use of unsupportive browsers is dropping rapidly. Torchbox are dropping support for IE7 wherever possible and now Microsoft have adopted a more forceful upgrade policy IE8 won’t be long behind. This means IE9 will be the lowest supported browser and with IE9 supporting SVG, this changes the world of web graphics considerably.

As SVG can be manipulated and animated live, we will likely see the web change quite a bit. Adverts, charts, indeed practically any graphic that isn’t a photograph could become far more interactive with far less effort. Exciting times are ahead!
fields.intro: It’s time to move on from raster image formats like JPG and PNG. Icon fonts and SVG are the future

fields.body:
You’ve just started reading a blog post. It is dark outside. You hear an owl hoot. You keep reading. Suddenly in the distance you hear a scream. You look up. 

Choice: Do you go outside? (turn to page 2)

Or: Do you keep reading the blog? (go to page 27)

I got well into these books for a while. I liked the fact I could decide where I would go next.

I think the modern day equivalent is interactive videos. Ones where you are given choices and the story develops based on your choices.

For the past few months, I’ve worked on an interactive video project with SGOSS - the School Governor recruitment charity. We’ll take a more detailed look at the ace campaign - which stars two of Torchbox Olly’s children and their friend - and its results in more detail in a future blog but for today I’d like to focus on the platform we used to make it happen.

Choice: Do you have a go at the interactive video now? (hit the play button below)

Or: Do you keep reading the blog (just scroll down a bit please)

So when it came to building the video, we could have used YouTube Annotations. But they don’t work on tablet or mobile. We could have programmed it ourselves. But that could have been tricky and time consuming. We chose to use Rapt Media’s platform which allows you to build interactive videos quickly and cost effectively (as we were working with a charity, Rapt gave a discount on their white label product).

I guess you always face challenges when developing content and I was pleased with the support Rapt gave us when we needed it, including out of hours. 

The video has done really well so far. It gives people the chance to make the sort of decisions which School Governors have to make on a day to day basis.

It allows the story to be told in a compelling way and a way which the user feels involved in.

The aim is to recruit new School Governors and early indications are it is doing exactly that.

If you think interactive video could help bring your story to life, please drop me an email at rob@torchbox.com or say hello at www.twitter.com/rsalmonuk

To find out more about Rapt Media, please visit www.raptmedia.com
fields.intro: Do you remember the Choose Your Own story adventure books? They went a little something like this...

fields.body:
We were delighted to win the four-way pitch for UX consultancy. Better still, we ended up building the whole site and creating an exciting new CMS, which we will be open sourcing - look out for more on this soon.


The RCA is one of the most inspiring and exciting organisations I could hope to work with. They totally embraced our collaborative, agile approach to running a project and my thanks go to their project leader, Octavia Reeve, who has been fantastic, and the wonderfully acronymed Web Task Force project board.

Even better, we worked with Research Studios, Neville Brody's design outfit, who delivered all the visual design. As well as having designed the BBC website (alongside all the other things that have made him one of the best known graphic designers in the UK), Neville is the Dean of the School of Communications at the RCA and recent RCA Visual Communication graduate, Jack Llewellyn, was a core member of the design team.

We had a couple of significant changes of direction, most notably RCA's decision, mid-project, to abandon Squiz CMS and commission us to develop a new CMS and implement the site on it. Despite these we were delighted to launch the project on schedule for the key 2014 REF deadlines.

My thanks also go to everyone who worked on our project team: Chris Rogers, Matthew Westcott, Dave Cranwell, Helen Chapman, Karl Hobley, Balazs Endrezs, Nick Smith.

The RCA site is driven by our new, blazing fast Python/Django CMS, which we will be launching as an open source project in early 2014. It integrates with EPrints for research records, and the College's LDAP server for authentication; it uses Stripe for donations, Elasticsearch for, um, search, Eventbrite for event booking, and it drives the screens around the College that tell students and staff what events are happening, every day. Thousands of images and records were imported from the previous site including all show data and profiles on previous students, current researchers, staff, images of artworks, research records, and news. The site is responsive and optimised for desktop, tablet and mobile.
fields.intro: Big week, last week. We launched the Royal College of Art website. If you aren't familiar with the RCA, it's the world's best graduate art and design school.

fields.body:
While not specifically designed for a single technology or skill set it was a great opportunity to meet people who built things for the web across a wide spectrum of technologies and products. The Fazeley Studios venue was an intriguing mix of marble, fine art and trendy office spaces and must be an inspiring place to work on a day to day basis.

The conference was keynoted by Syd Lawrence (of instac.at fame - possibly the finest use of the Austrian TLD?) who, through the medium of animated gif slides, reminded us of the positive effects hack days have both to the development of personal tech skills as well as being able to fold those experiences back into the workplace. It's important to periodically remind yourself that you shouldn't be working just for the sake of work, but for fun. Play/fun/making something... these are great motivating factors and whether it's with Lego, wood, paint or Javascript (other languages are available!) we should all strive to enjoy what we create.

There were great session on good API design from Lorna Jane, an introduction to Clojure and how it improves on Java, building algorithms to make rhyming couplets from Twitter with Go, and a really fun demonstration how node.js is used to power quadracopters. For those of you who haven't seen one of these Parrot AR drones they're pretty amazing, and Andrew Nesbitt was controlling one over wifi with an xbox360 controller and later, a Javascript library for a Kinect. We didn't even have any injuries in the audience.

There were sessions on the latest tools for automating workflows and dependencies, such as grunt.js and bower. I've used grunt.js a little over the Summer and I'm keen to put it to use on a future Drupal project where we expect it to compliment tools such as drush.

The conference was a great opportunity for me to find out first hand about Riak - an open source distributed database for people with lots, and lots, and lots of data who need fault tolerance and availability over data consistency. The guys from Basho were really great to chat to and we've now got The Little Book of Riak in our office. Next time I'd love to stick around for the hack day too, but overall I find conferences like Hackference are great for taking stock of other technologies and sparking ideas for both existing and new projects. For instance, I'm always struggling to remember which bin goes out at the end of the week... there's a potential side project in the form of a page scraper/parser for my local council site and a weekly email/tweet to remind me.
fields.intro: I was fortunate enough to get the opportunity to attend this conference/hackathon event at the Fazeley Studios in Birmingham at the end of August.

fields.body:
Their volunteer data geeks work with the data collected by NGOs, in order to make new insights "that can solve the most complex and intractable problems we face".

The volunteers come from all sort of industries and give their time for free, either in weekend events known as "DataDives" or longer projects of up to six months known as "DataCorps". DataKind is also spreading its wings worldwide by setting up related organisations in other countries, most recently with DataKind UK.

DataKind already had a design, so the challenge for us was to find a CMS that matched their needs and budget, and we decided on Mezzanine. We chose it because:

  • It's free and open source
  • It's written in Django
  • Customisations are relatively straightforward
  • It gives you the benefit of simple, complete control of the HTML markup at the templating level.

It's a fairly immature, open source project so it isn't the best documented system in the world, and the administration interface wouldn't object to a little UX love, but it was fun and satisfying to work with Mezzanine - and we can easily hack on it in Django.

And, working transatlantically, with no physical meetings, went pretty well (thanks Craig for getting up early for some of those calls!).

DataKind are a great organisation, and are lovely to work with. If you're a data geek, check out the opportunities.
fields.intro: I recently had the pleasure of project managing and co-building a new site for DataKind, a New York-based organisation, which brings together data scientists and NGOs.

fields.body:
At Torchbox, we've started to invite interesting people to join us for lunch on Friday. They get a free meal in exchange for a short talk about what they do — everyone's happy! 

Last Friday we were treated to a talk by Niko Brian, a sound engineer/sound recordist/sound designer and composer from Oxford. He was recommended to us as someone who could help with sound design on an animation project we were working on.

Niko's talk was about his Record and Ride project, which saw him undertaking a 5-month cycling tour of Europe; recording local musicians as he went. Almost all of his accomodation on the trip was provided by the generous musicians and friends he met on his travels. He started out with a very loose plan of what he wanted to achieve but ended up travelling to France, Belgium, Holland, Germany, Poland, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, Italy (Bari), Greece and Israel. The musicians that he recorded would hook him up with musicians in other countries and that would become the next destination on his tour. Over the five months, he recorded in some pretty amazing places, including a sewer and an abandoned cold-war Radome in Berlin.

It was great to hear about Niko's adventure and about the serendipity you're exposed to by putting yourself out of your comfort zone.

Find out more about the trip and listen to some of the recordings he made at his website: record-and-ride.com

If you'd like to give a short talk at Torchbox, get in touch.
fields.intro: A 5-month sound recording adventure in Europe.

fields.body:
For the past few months I’ve been spending my evenings helping to arrange Frontend United with a dedicated team of Drupal users. There were times when I wanted to give up and it didn’t seem like we were going to pull it off but I plodded on through and last weekend it all came together.

Frontend United tries to pick unusual and creative locations, this year we raised the bar and picked a nightclub, we hired the über-trendy Cargo in Shoreditch, it wasn’t without its pitfalls but it was a very inspiring and stimulating space for our attendees.  You can see all the buzz about Frontend United at eventifier.

Even though the core of the event is Drupal we tried hard to focus on frontend topics which do not solely need to be applied to Drupal. As Bruce Lawson mentioned in his entertaining closing talk on Saturday, we had provided a browser sandwich: Christian Heilmann and Bruce were first and last of our fantastic speakers on Saturday. The conference started off with an opening session from Christian, he showed us what excites him in the web world and got some of us excited about FirefoxOS. I would like to tell you more about this, but to be honest at this point I was outside the club with the other team members doing a little dance, ecstatic that we had actually made it - it was actually happening!

We covered a broad range of topics over the weekend. Zélia Sakhi spoke about the Golden ratio in her quest for beauty in design and reminded us to try and apply the techniques we learned in art school to our websites. Edward O'Riordan whisked us through 800 years of art history to remind us that code is tool in creating modern day artwork. Then at the other end of the scale we had very specific Drupal talks from Théodore Biadala about Javascript in Drupal and how to make it better, whilst Matt Fielding  joined James Panton to reprise the famous session on the Death of a Themer, from Drupalcamp London: revealing to us who killed the themer; telling us how they, as designer and developer, work together harmoniously. 

At the after party Alex Pott and Kristof De Jaeger committed some very important code to Drupal 8 core, which was met with a round of applause and cheers from all of the attendees. This mega patch will make deploying sites with many different field settings so much easier in future: a relief to all frontend designers who occasionally have to tinker with deployments. 

I feel that even though there was such a wide range of sessions there were a few recurring take home messages:

  • Communicate with the team. Constant communication with all involved helps to stay focused and achieve the desired outcome, try new things and overcome obstacles before they become unmanageable.
  • Design in the browser. Eliminating Photoshop as much as possible and sometimes even wireframes to get to the desired outcome faster.
  • Keep pushing yourself, not only in web development but in life.

In my personal experience, the Drupal community continue to support me and push me through all aspects of my life, not just the crazy theming goodness that Drupal brings. Helping to organise Frontend United was my way to give a little back.
fields.intro: Justine tells us of her time organising Frontend United and how it all came together last weekend.

fields.body:
Some months ago now I gave a Torchbox University talk on Display Suite, a Drupal module that we use on pretty much all of our Drupal based sites. More recently, Justine, J-P and I went to DrupalCamp London where everyone was inspired by James Panton's session, 'Death of a themer', which proposed using tools like Display Suite to simplify Drupal's markup (and incidentally to generate unemployment by firing themers).

So to back up a bit, what does Display Suite actually do? Drupal's standard markup output is not the cleanest, and has often been referred to as 'div soup' (in other words endless nested div tags with different classes applied). Drupal has a system of template files which allows you to control this markup and the layout on pages of the site. These use a mixture of the PHP templating language and theming functions to determine what the page actually looks like. Of course if you're not in the business of changing Drupal's default output then you don't need template files at all, but if you want to create a good-looking site that doesn't just look like an "out-of-the-box" Drupal site then it's pretty inevitable that you're going to have to dig into template files at some point. They're not the most straightforward things to get your head around, and it's traditionally the job of themer to take Drupal's default output, pass it through the magic of the template files, and output some markup that is reasonably sane and lays the page out how the designer intended.

Step in Display Suite. This module allows you to make flexible changes to the page layout using a GUI rather than via template files. While core Drupal allows some layout changes, Display Suite gives much more fine-grained control over how you order and arrange your content on the page.  With the Display Suite Extras module enabled you can pretty much control the markup for every single field (simple unit of content) that you output. You can set your own classes, and use any tag you like for example '<section>' and '<article>' instead of endless '<divs>'. Behind the scenes, Display Suite still creates theming functions, but you no longer have to code them from scratch. This can help to give more consistency in your markup across the site, but also increases security. Display Suite is thoroughly tested by the community and regularly updated to prevent cross site scripting attacks, in a way that your own theming code can never equal.

In my Torchbox University talk I gave a detailed overview of how to use Display Suite. I don't plan to write that up in full here, but if you want to find out more I can recommend this series of videos which covers the topic in more detail than the drupal docs.

So as I mentioned, Torchbox use Display Suite for pretty much all of our builds. How does this differ from James Panton's proposal of killing the themer? James' proposal was to ditch almost all of the template files or pare them down to the very bare minimum. He recommended never using a template file, and always using modules (Display Suite included, but he also recommends Semantic Panels). His argument is that this gives the designer complete control of the markup and CSS, makes for more consistency in the markup, and means that template files don't get abused with model logic (this basically means putting more deep level code such as database queries into the template file when it belongs elsewhere).

But there are big drawbacks to all of this. Apart from the fact that moving all the markup up to be entered with 'point-and-click' just doesn't *feel* right, it means that it isn't under version control. This basically means that there is no way to see a history of changes to the markup - you can only ever see the state of it at the current time - so if a big mistake is made, it's not easy to roll back. Secondly, and worse, if someone added some dodgy PHP into a code field (hopefully not something anyone would be silly enough to do), there’s a danger of whitescreening your whole site, with no recovery options apart from raw database updates.  Finally, given that we have a development build, a staging site and a production site for every Drupal build, the pointing and clicking potentially has to be done 3 times, unless we use Features to help distribute the  changes, which has its own complications. (As an aside, the deployment of configuration changes looks set to become much much easier in Drupal 8, but that's for another blog post).

For our purposes Display Suite is great for setting up some display defaults for our White label build - the basis from which we start new Drupal sites. We also use it widely to help with different layouts of the same content - for example an article on the site might appear on a page in its own right, as well as in summarised form on a listing page, in a newsletter or in an RSS feed. Each of these versions of the same content needs to be output in different ways, and Display Suite handles that well. But as for ditching all our template files and killing our themers? We'll probably hold on that for now.
fields.intro: Some months ago now I gave a Torchbox University talk on Display Suite, a Drupal module that we use on pretty much all of our Drupal based sites.

fields.body:
How did you make a tweet talking Moose?

Inspired by the deer of Cornbury Park, the talking moose scene in Fawlty Towers, and Tom wanting to use 'Text to Speech', we came up with the idea of Manuel the tweet talking moose.

We ordered a fake moose head from an ebay reseller in Canada, and called Tod (an engineer friend of Olly's, who can make anything from coil guns to bollock daggers) to talk about 'enhancements'.

One of our devs, Matthew, hooked into the Twitter API to harvest tweets with #tbxmoose in, put together a node.js script to pipe them into the Festival open source speech synthesiser and got it all running on a Raspberry Pi, a computer small enough to fit in a Moose head.

Meanwhile Tod dusted off his animatronics chops, lopped Manuel's lower jaw off, added the necessary bits and bobs and put him back together again complete with fake teeth and lolling tongue.

The audio feed attaches to this handy little Autotalk Interface Board, which moves the servo in response to audio or speech. The signal is split so it goes into the Autotalk board and into a speaker. Now we can hear Manuel speaking and see his jaw moving, at the same time.

Sarah and James designed and built the site, We rigged up a webcam, hooked it into Ustream  and Manuel went live.

Was he a success?

Good question. The figures tell of a pretty successful Christmas stunt:

  • Manuel was live for about a week and was viewed 22,316 times
  • The biggest referrer was Raspberry Pi with 2.667 followed by Spiegel and Reddit
  • Ustream clocked up 2453.4 viewing hours
  • Manuel was tweeted 8046 times with another 1201 messages via the web form (which we turned off on day two)
  • Best celebrity tweet was by Brian Blessed
  • Most popular tweet: 'There's a moose loose about this hoose'
  • Number of tweets blocked by profanity filter: 349

However, Manuel was not the perfect office mate. He wasn't always witty and original. He often repeated himself (normally one word over and over). He  mis-spelt his way around the swear filter. He was scrupulous when reading out backslashes and other special character aitch-tea-tea-pea-colon-backslash-backslash and so on. 

Did I mention his accent? Well lets just say that open source text to speech voices aren't as polished as the nice lady on your TomTom.

Probably the worst thing about Manuel was that he could be senselessly offensive at times. There are plenty of potty mouthed Twitter users out there, and they don't mind what goes on their Twitter streams. Of course, we knew this might happen, but we figured we could take it. Some of the time, it turned out that we couldn't!

So, what has become of him?

Manuel's servo, or the audio driver, packed up on Dec 24th. This was pretty much expected as he wasn't specced to last. We have spares of both, but haven't got round to fixing him yet.

I'd like to fire him up again, and have him speak out @torchbox tweets in the office. We don't get THAT many, and they generally aren't offensive. 

So, what are you going to do next year?

Nothing that speaks out loud in our office, that's for sure! 

In fact, we may take a break next year. After doing many cool things over the last few years, we don't want to do it just because we feel that we should; we don't want it to be like that. So, we may not do a 'Christmas card' next year. Perhaps we'll turn our attention to 'valentine's day' or 'bonfire day' or 'cycle to work day' instead. Any which way, we'll do our next fun site because we are excited by an idea, rather than because we feel we ought to.

Adios Manuel, RIP.
fields.intro: As you may know, we built a tweet, talkin' moose last Christmas, rather than send out a more conventional Christmas card. Before we forget him completely, I want to review the short, and not always 'sweet' life of Manuel the Moose.

fields.body:
Email templates aren’t the sexiest projects to be working on but they can be an important part of an organisation’s digital marketing. Nuffield Trust came to us with a set of wireframes but I asked Claire Richardson, our client at Nuffield Trust if she’d mind us trying something a bit different. It was a big departure from the existing approach, but they were interested in our ideas.

There were a few issues with Nuffield Trust’s existing emails that we helped to address.

Copywriting

Each email felt like a formal letter from their Director including a “Dear…” and a signature at the bottom. For a modern and forward thinking organisation this was coming across as stuffy. We suggested breaking down the copy into discrete points - each with an individual action. People don’t have time to read long emails and tend to scan headlines. Breaking down the content in this way made the information more engaging and easier to scan.

Layout

Over the years, HTML emails have morphed into mini versions of an organisation’s website. The problem with this is that multi-column layouts are hard to scan — should I be reading top to bottom or left to right? I wanted Nuffield Trust to use a single column and focus on a single lead item at the top, listing other content, in order of importance, underneath. People glance quickly at newsletters, so you have to get them interested straight away; we lead with a big striking image followed by a nicely laid out list of content below, allowing recipients to easily scan through the items. There’s a nice blog from Campaign Monitor that includes some eye-tracking research to illustrate why this is a good idea: Email usability: The science of keeping it short and sweet

Mobile

When the existing email templates were originally conceived, mobile wasn’t really a consideration. However, a significant number of Nuffield Trusts subscribers were opening their emails on smartphones and would have been finding them difficult to read as the text was so small. With all email templates, you’re very much at the mercy of the email client but we were able to do lots with the iPhone’s native Mail app, which made up a large proportion of Nuffield Trust’s mobile users. There were some other benefits too — Nuffield Trust’s main typeface, Futura, is a standard iOS font, meaning we could keep the emails on brand and fallback to Helvetica and Arial for other users. Campaign Monitor’s Responsive Mobile Guide is a great starting point to see what’s possible with mobile on email these days.

We took a mobile first approach to the redesign, which helped to trim down the content to the minimum that needs to be there to get users to click through to full articles or to download reports.

The result

Nuffield Trust were really pleased with the end result and so were we. Click through rates instantly went up by 10% and the emails look modern and are easier to read both of desktop and mobile. However, one of the best things to come out of the re-design is that Nuffield Trust have changed the way they communicate with their audience. Gone are the long, stuffy formal letters and scrappy images, which have been replaced but eye-catching photos and snappy copy. Since the redesign, Claire Richardson and the rest of the organisation have done a great job with editorial — keeping the copy short and using images well. I now get a little glow of satisfaction every time one of their emails drops into my inbox.


Sign up for Nuffield Trust's newsletter here: 
nuffieldtrust.org.uk/newsletter

Follow Wes on twitter: 
@wesayso
fields.intro: Nuffield Trust asked us to redesign all of their email templates, wanting a facelift to bring their templates in line with the rest of their site. We ended up completely rethinking the way they communicate with their subscribers, leading to a big improvement in click-throughs.

fields.body:
Plagiarism alert

I'll start with an admission; most of this post isn't my own work. Almost all of it (other than the references to guerrillas) are from the wonderful Steve Krug. I strongly recommend that you purchase a copy of Rocket Surgery Made Easy.

Guerrilla? Really?!

By guerrilla I don't mean shooting people, blowing up trains, growing a beard, or living in the woods (although I have no problem with you doing the latter two should you wish).

What I mean is:

  • taking matters into your own hands
  • acting swiftly
  • working in small teams
  • using low/no budget
  • still extremely effective.

Never done any user testing?

In short, if you haven't then you should consider the following:

  • it improves the usability of your site
  • if you're running a process with a financial benefit it increases revenue
  • you'll end up with happier users, which has a positive impact on brand and spend
  • you may think that your site works fine, but there are always unknown unknowns when it comes to user satisfaction
  • a selfish point but – it is always fun and fascinating!

Hopefully that should convince. So, here's how to do guerrilla user testing.

Step 1: Hunt for problems

You need to know what to test; there can be many sources and even if your site is perfect one of these options will give you a starting point:

  • known issues (you'll keep a spreadsheet of these)
  • important process(es) like donating or signing up to a campaign
  • analytics – exit pages, pages with high bounce rate
  • helpdesk / contact form feedback.

Step 2: Write a script

You'll use a script in the test to guide your participant. It's important to spend time on this, as getting the tasks right is crucial for good results.

  • decide upon start point (a page in your site)
  • decide on the tasks that you want the participant to perform. No more than 5–10. They should be relevant to the overall problem that you're trying to test
  • asking for general feedback is OK e.g. "What is your impression of..." – but make sure that you use open questions (ones that can't be answered yes or no)
  • use appropriate language
  • write a nice introduction giving the participant the background to the project and what the test is about - also make sure that you tell them that it isn't a test of them but of the website!

Once you're all done, run through the script with a colleague. It should be no more than 30 minutes.

Step 3: Recruit some participants

You only need 5 participants (so says NNGroup). Start out with colleagues and friends, then expand to invite people who are visiting your office.

The key is to make sure that they know it will be fun, and not a test of them. Bribes, in the form of pastries and doughnuts (mmm, doughnuts) are vital.

Step 4: Practicalities

Book a single room for a half day (don't attempt to swap rooms) with enough space for at least 5 people, and make sure people know where it is.

You will need a computer, obviously, with internet. The computer should have a normal mouse – trackpads aren't great – and a normal monitor to make it easier for you to see. Make sure the participant knows where the browser back button is.

Your assistant (more on them in a bit) should not be too obtrusively placed, and ideally out of the line of vision of the participant.

We advocate making the testing a spectator sport: invite other people (hey, if your CEO is free they can come). You will need a large monitor/projector on to which the participant's display is duplicated. Getting other people in helps spread the word that user testing is cool.

Don't forget to nudge people the day / morning before; no-shows are very annoying.

Step 5: Being a good moderator

Running a user test is called moderation; you will be a moderator. Being a good one requires a little bit of practice; here are some tips:

  • be nice, friendly and polite; a 'strict teacher' approach will put off your participant
  • stick to the script. Mostly; sometimes letting a participant explore a path you'd not included in the script can be interesting, but don't be afraid to stop them and return
  • ask your participant to speak their thoughts out loud whilst they're browsing
  • watch their body language as well as listening as it will give you clues if they are having problems before they speak – if they don't say anything then it gives you a chance to prompt
  • conversely, pauses at the right time can be useful as the participant will tend to fill the void by speaking their thoughts.

Step 6: Being a good note-taker

You'll need an assistant, whose main purpose is to take notes on the tests. They should:

  • sit out of the line of sight of the participant
  • keep quiet
  • record a pass/fail for each task
  • note important points only, concisely
  • *do* note down language used, especially if it varies from that used on your site.

Step 7: Analysis

You don't need to write War and Peace. In fact, please don't. Analysis should be done immediately after the last user test, ideally over a cup of your favourite beverage.

Keep it short, just bullet points for each task, and ensure that you have noted any recommendations that you can think of. Prioritise the key fails and recommendations (if you have any at this stage – don't worry if you don't – often a designer or developer will come up with recommendations for you).

It should end up being a side of A4 - nothing more.

Step 8: Getting things done

Don't worry about trying to fix everything. Set yourself the target of fixing the top three issues within a month. If you can do others (i.e. that are quick/cheap) too, then great.

For other issues, keep a log. You can work on these in the next round of testing and improvements.

Don't forget to re-test any improvements that you make – so back to Step 1 and start to plan your next testing session!

We recommend setting up a regular programme of testing; once a month or once every two months.
fields.intro: Face-to-face user testing is great but getting the budget and time to do it with an agency is difficult. In this post, I advocate guerrilla user testing - quicker and much cheaper but no less effective in improving the user experience of your site.

fields.body:
a. Why do research?

Understand needs
Creating a website can be looked at as nothing more than a vehicle for the satisfaction of the needs of its users. If they can't find what they're looking for, they will give up or become frustrated, something we wish to avoid.

At Torchbox we want to keep users happy; to do this you need to understand them, their motivation and their needs.

Underpin your content strategy
As well as happy users, research is vital for creating great content. What do they want to read about? What phrases do your users use? Will they want to read your content on a mobile device? Without the answers to these simple questions a content strategy will be useless.

Make evidence-based decisions
Last of all, research is used as evidence to make decisions. This avoids the most senior person in the room getting what he or she wants based on their opinion - the evidence allows you to present an argument from a perspective of research, and allows you to back up any decisions with evidence!

b. What do we need to know?

It's easy to become overwhelmed by the volume of research data so this is a helpful way of structuring the information you get. So I like to guide the research with some overall goals - things about users we need to know. These are: domain knowledge, context, language, needs and tasks. Let's look at each in turn.

Domain knowledge
This is general information about the area in which the client is operating and often contains information about the potential audiences and their behaviour. As Torchbox often work with charities, our knowledge of the charity 'domain' is good, but it's always useful to get a deeper understanding.

Context
This is their motivation for visiting and what they are thinking about.

Example: I'm a bright 6th form student interested in studying botany at university. I'd like to look at what the different courses offer me.

Language
This is simply the words the person uses in phrasing their problem.

Example: botany, degree, course

It ensures that our labelling (for example in the site map and headings) reflects the user's language, and it's good search-friendly content.

Needs
What the user would like to achieve on the site - often phrased as questions or "I need to..." statements.

Example: I need to get the course content and tutors for the botany degree course.

Tasks
These are simply the specific steps that the user has to take to achieve their goal.

Examples:

  • Search for 'botany course' on site search
  • Look at outline of course
  • Download a PDF of the course
  • Bookmark the page for later.

c. The techniques

With that framework in mind, let's look at the techniques.

#1 Existing research
This might be market research commissioned by the client, or wider reports/studies from the sector in which they are operating.

This is good for an audience overview and overall domain knowledge.

It can take time to sift through research but the benefits are that you get a bedrock of understanding - without which it's easy to miss key findings from other types of research.

#2 Surveys
Surveys are great for quantitative data about audience groups. We'll often run surveys at the start of a project if there's no data from the client. As well as the standard quantitative information we'll ask behavioural and ethnographic questions tailored to the client and the project, culminating in questions about needs that the site can satisfy.

We make use of Forms in Google Drive (as they're free) or, if more advanced branching logic is required, Survey Monkey.

Recruitment is done via a variety of methods depending on the scope of the project, although we often use a dedicated screening tool like ethn.io to avoid having to insert Javascript for every single research tool we use.

Top tip: ask survey participants if they are willing to be contacted about further user research - it's a good way of getting participants for later studies.

#3 Google Analytics
If you are redeveloping an existing site, there is a mass of information on your users in Google Analytics. To keep focused, try to pick up 10 key findings. The best places to look are:

  • Popular content and landing pages (shows what people are interested in, and where they are arriving at your site)
  • Exit pages (what they don't like, and good to filter this by search term to see if you can work out why)
  • Site search (for language).

If you don't have site search set up in analytics, do so now; it's free and an excellent source of user insight.

#4 Contextual inquiry
Contextual inquiry is a method involving observing users interacting with your product / site whilst trying to achieve a particular goal or task. It doesn't involve snooping, but does involve:

  • Observing users at work; people give more away in their behaviour than in their words
  • Listening in on phone calls, e.g. at call centres.

It's not something that we use frequently at Torchbox but it's very valuable for the more complex web applications that we build.

#5 Interviews
We use interviews extensively to find out about users - usually choosing to do 2-3 interviews per audience group. These can be over-the-phone or face-to-face.

In my experience they are singularly the best way of finding out everything about your users - from background and context to language to specific tasks. The one-on-one nature of the conversation means that you get much richer information than from any other source.

If you do plan on doing this, prepare a list of questions, and practise on friends/colleagues first. Don't be afraid to leave pauses, and don't ask leading or closed questions!

#6 Focus groups
Focus groups are good for gauging the opinion of a wide range of people at once. We tend not to run them with external audiences as the quality of the information isn't as good as from interviews (as some people don't like talking as part of a group), but we do use focus group techniques when conducting internal workshops.

Focus group moderation is something of an art that requires practice; you will also need someone taking notes during the group. Analysing the results of focus groups can be tricky, as discussion often shifts around quickly. Unless the moderator is skilled in steering the group, the information can be unstructured and, at worst, irrelevant to the project.

#7 Card sorts
Card sorts are where you create cards for all of the items in your site and get users to group them together. They are the best tool for deciding upon your content structure and sitemap.

There are two kinds:

  • Open - participants come up with their own categories
  • Closed - you give participants categories into which they put items.

There are some really good online tools for this - Optimal Sort and SimpleSort.

These tend to be used when researching the structure for new projects but it's worth running a closed sort to analyse whether your current IA is sensible!

#8 User testing
It is almost always startling how people interact with your site, even for what you think are the most basic tasks. So, whilst this technique warrants a separate post entirely, it is still important to acknowledge that it's a source of user research.

It's simple to do - start with people in your office, friends, anyone who can use a computer. Come up with a list of 5 goals that are important to your site, and ask them to complete them!

We recommend one-on-one testing as it gets you more useful information as you can talk to them. However we do also use remote (online) testing as it gets you more participants, and quantitative data.

#9 AB and multi-variate testing
This is where you test alternative pages. The alternatives could be as simple as changing the wording of a button, or entirely new layouts.

It's done using online tools like Optimizely or Google's Content Experiments.

Google use it extensively to test versions of their apps, but it's not just about usability - you can find out what language suits your users better, and how to present a task.

#10 Personas
Personas aren't so much a research technique but more of a way of summing up all that you've found during research. They are models of people, synthesised from data. They allow us to design to satisfy the group of people represented by that persona.

In particular, the 'Needs', and 'Tasks' that you've uncovered should form the bedrock of the persona. Unlike traditional market research reports, the needs of your personas are more important than their demographics. The gov.uk design project built a tool specifically to capture needs - the needotron.

As products of research, they are vital for information designers, humanising the design process. They are also excellent tools to settle arguments (what would persona 'Jasmine' need - not what does 'Senior Client' want), and a helpful summary of audiences for marketers.

We use them on all our major projects.

Summary

Understanding user needs is vital for the development of a successful website. Hopefully this post will have given you some ideas of a framework for filing all the insights that you find, and some techniques for getting those insights.
fields.intro: Digital tools are interactive: users come to them with a goal in mind and tasks they need to achieve. Making your users happy means understanding them and designing to meet their needs. In this blog post I look at how you can do this.

fields.body:
Torchbox were invited to the Google Engage: Box of Tricks 2012 event in London on Friday 23 November 2012. Here are the insights that got us excited:

Client-agency relationship

  • Is monthly reporting always necessary? Some agencies are no longer creating monthly reports and are instead setting up dashboards so their clients can log in themselves and see reports on demand.

Mobile

Here's how Adidas designed a mobile attribution model to assign a value to clicks on the store locator link on their mobile website:

  • They assumed that 20% of people who use the store locator will visit a store.
  • 20% of those who visit a store will make a purchase.
  • Average in-store purchase is $80.
  • Average value of a click on the store locator is $3.20 (0.2 x 0.2 x 80).

Clicks on the store locator are therefore valuable to their business and were encouraged by placing it in a more prominent position at the top of the mobile page.

YouTube

  • People watch on average two hours of video a week on YouTube. This places YouTube on the same level of influence as TV channels such as BBC2 and Channel 4.
  • YouTube advertisers don't pay for clicks when users skip their ads in the first 5 seconds.
  • 20% of users choose not to skip ads on YouTube.
  • Charities and not-for-profit organisations should apply for the YouTube Nonprofit Program to get an optimised YouTube channel (worth about £40,000).

Social media

  • Organisations should set up and maintain a Google+ page to enable the "knowledge panel" in the right-hand column of Google SERPs and dominate their brand terms.

Google Analytics

  • Segment internal site search queries by paid search users to see where your landing pages are falling short: what users were expecting to see but didn't find. This is also a good source of new AdWords keywords.
  • Segment "true new visitors" with a custom advanced segment by excluding brand keywords, email campaigns, direct visitors and users who login.
  • "Universal Analytics" is coming in 2013, providing the functionality to track the same user's actions across multiple channels and devices. Google plan to make it possible to import CRM data into Google Analytics.

AdWords

  • One of the most creative uses we've seen of Google Trends is using it to predict who's going to win the X-Factor final without actually having to watch the show! According to recent search trends in the UK, you should have put your money on Union J - whoever they are - in mid-November. It's a good job we didn't because apparently they got kicked off last week! However, this method did correctly predict the US presidential election.
  • New AdWords features to look out for in 2013 include the communication extension, which will allow advertisers to collect email sign-ups in search ads.
  • Google will also be rolling out remarketing for search ads. This will help advertisers retarget the 96% of users who click on an ad and leave without performing the advertiser's desired action and the 70% of users who click on an ad but abandon the shopping cart.

The importance of the long tail:

  • 20% of daily searches haven't occurred on Google in the past 3 months.
  • Nearly 40% of search queries are longer than three words.
fields.intro: Read our highlights from Google's recent event in London. Topics include the client-agency relationship, mobile, YouTube, social media, Google Analytics and AdWords.

fields.body:
Not all of our work involves Django or Drupal. Although we love them, there are times when a considerably simplified approach to content management is all that's necessary.

We've recently launched several small sites which don't need to be regularly updated by a large number of editors. In these situations a custom Django application, even an out-the-box Django CMS could be overkill. Drupal similarly might be a sledgehammer to this proverbial nut. Instead, we've turned to a 'Static Site Generator'.

There are several static site generators out there: Jekyll, Hyde, Middleman and more. Jekyll has arguably the larger following and for this reason (among others) is our site generator of choice.

For oxford.geeknights.net, digitaloxford.com and symplectic.co.uk we're using Jekyll's limited, predetermined concept of chronological, related content e.g blog posts, news items etc. The news or blog item can be written without HTML, using markdown or similar, then Jekyll converts it to HTML and inserts the item automatically into the listing of news/blogs on the site. This is pretty much the limit of content management in most static site generators. It's very basic, but it's often all we need.

Behind this we're using Github Pages as the host. Github Pages is a service in which a Github repository is used as the source directory for a website which Github host for you. Pages is particularly handy because it supports Jekyll projects by default. If you commit a Jekyll-configured directory into your repository, Github can compile, deploy and host your Jekyll website whenever you make a "push" request to Github.

If a simpler editing interface than Github is needed, we'd recommend prose.io. It provides a simplified git repository browser with a file editor and new file creator (something that at time of writing Github doesn't provide) that neatly sidesteps detailed command line git knowledge.

Version control, code editor, deployment tool and hosting all rolled into one and for free? Sign me up!

The fun doesn't have to stop here. We use Jekyll for front end projects even when we're not hosting or deploying the site ourselves. And, sometimes not even for websites at all!

Where the deliverables are purely front end files (HTML, JS, CSS) Jekyll can still help with the templating. We've used it recently generating sets of Campaign Monitor HTML email templates and dynamic maps for the World Economic Forum. Jekyll comes with the Liquid templating engine (from Shopify) so if you're componentising sections of code for reuse over a variety of templates or simply sharing the same header/footer between several similar pages, Liquid helps you with a very simple syntax. 

Our client doesn't necessarily know or care what Jekyll is in this instance. What matters is that our code is maintainable and modular and this translates to clear benefits to everyone.

Previously front end developers might have delivered HTML mixed with PHP or Apache SSIs - they would have needed some kind of "include" technology during development. They'd probably deliver the files to the client as they are, accompanied with documentation about installing the require software and caveats about how the HTML they've delivered isn't actually complete without Apache/PHP so can't be double-clicked to be viewed. All in all it wasn't a particularly satisfying experience for the client or developer.

With Jekyll we're delivering complete, static HTML pages which can be launched straight away or drag-dropped into the browser. When reviewing files is this simple, quick sign-off, rapid iteration and design in the browser becomes more realistic too.

Interestingly President Obama's 2011/12 fundraising campaign was recently blogged about by Kyle Rush and it turns out they too were using static site generators - specifically Jekyll - at the core of their technology stack.

What's clear from our experience and Kyle's is that having the right tools for the job is vital and Jekyll has become an invaluable tool in our box.
fields.intro: We've found Jekyll to be really useful in the creation of websites and in the delivery of HTML for use in other CMS. Combined with Github Pages, it's a powerful toolset.

fields.body:
Last week was the seventh anniversary of the launch of Google Analytics, so we decided to mark the occasion by highlighting seven features you should be aware of and one new kid on the block that might revolutionise how you track user journeys on your site. We'll also propose some best practice guidelines and pose one problem we haven't figured out yet.

But first, naming of parts.

Account vs Property vs View

Google Analytics n00bs are sometimes confused by the terminology of the GA structure. I got my head round it this way:

An account is the top level. But what's the difference between a property and a view? A property in GA could be your main website, your blog or a mobile app. A view (aka profile) is a subset of data about a property. It's at the view level that you access reports and filter your data. You can set up a view to exclude traffic from your organisation's office IP address or to isolate traffic from your Google Grants ads. We'll revisit views in our best practice tips later on.

8 things you should be aware of

#1 Tracking multiple domains or subdomains

You can track traffic across multiple domains or subdomains in a single GA property. This is useful if your user journeys spans more than one domain or subdomain - for example, users might read about an event on www.example.com/event, buy a ticket on shop.example.com and return to www.example.com/thank-you for confirmation of their order. Ideally, your conversion funnel would track that whole process. If you didn't have multiple subdomain tracking set up, you'd lose track of users when they left the event page for the shop.

We'd like to see new GA instances set up with multiple domain tracking as standard so that you can accommodate new subdomains in your default property at a later date. If you want reports on a subdomain in isolation, you can create a separate filtered profile for that.

#2 Advanced segments

These are filters you apply to your data after it's in the account. For example, you can compare paid and non-paid search traffic. You can also define custom segments. We created an advanced segment to exclude one of our client's branded keywords from their search traffic reports.

#3 Event tracking

You can track user actions (or "events") such as a PDF downloads, clicks on a video's play button or even clicks on your navigation links. GA now allows you to convert events into conversion goals and import them into AdWords so you can better optimise your ad campaigns.

#4 Ecommerce tracking

Not all sites have a need for ecommerce tracking, but for any that collect donations or sell products, this is essential. You'll need to install a bit of extra code to get it working.

#5 Google Analytics debugger

There's a handy Chrome extension that shows you what data is passed to GA when a page loads.

#6 Site search

If you have a search function on your site, set this up to gather users' search queries. Next time you redesign your site architecture, you'll know what they couldn't find. It's also a great source of SEO and PPC keywords and can highlight gaps in your site's content or navigation.

#7 Content experiments

Formerly known as Google Website Optimizer but now fully integrated into GA, content experiments enable you to run A/B tests on your pages to compare the effectiveness of different designs and layouts. Use it to optimize landing or conversion pages.

#8 Google Tag Manager

Finally, the new kid on the block. Google launched this product on 1 October 2012 to help marketers manage all their tracking tags in one place. Install a single snippet of code in the <body> and define which tags are fired with rules you set in Google Tag Manager. You can use this to manage standard tags for Google Analytics and AdWords as well as custom tags e.g. for a checkout process or confirmation page. Once it's set up, marketers can create tags for new campaigns and products without further technical assistance from a developer.

Google Analytics best practice tips

  • Leave a default GA view untouched to gather all data. If you're going to apply filters, create separate views…
  • …For example, exclude your organisation's office IP address in a new view.
  • Insert the GA tracking snippet immediately before the closing </head> tag, not in the <body>…
  • …If you do, you'll be able to verify your site easily in Google Webmaster Tools.
  • Associate your Webmaster Tools account with your GA account in the admin property settings to import SEO data on search queries and landing pages into the traffic sources report.
  • If you've got an AdWords account, link it to GA via your Google Analytics property settings.

Now that you've read all our advice, how about a little payback?

A problem we'd like you to fix

We haven't yet figured out how to set up event tracking on embedded third-party code such as Vimeo, SoundCloud and Slideshare. If you know a good solution, get in touch with me on Twitter @domeheid.

Torchbox University sessions are held weekly (normally on Wednesdays). They last for up to an hour including Q & A and clients and friends are welcome to attend. Follow us on Twitter for notifications of upcoming sessions.

This page was updated on 19 December 2014.
fields.intro: Google Analytics is full of hidden treasures that some website owners don't use. Learn about eight features you should know about and follow our best practice tips.

fields.body:
OK, OK, the CMS is not dead,  I’m just being provocative. For people who do not know how to write HTML, being able to publish fresh and new content with just some basic skills is essential to ensuring great ideas reach the web. 

However, I’m concerned that enabling a writer/journalist/marketing executive to control every aspect of their website has some serious costs to the overall usability of a site. It’s unthinkable that a writer would be left to layout the page of Hello magazine or the Guardian Weekender, so why do we expect it of web content editors? 

Because content managed pages are designed to work with all kinds of content, they have to be, by their very nature, quite generic. Wouldn’t it be nice if the design reflected the story?

Some content is well suited to being fully content managed: blogs, homepages,and other things that need to be written quickly in response to current events. However, some content has a much longer life and I believe that this content should be treated with more care and attention. 

As an example, let’s take a look at Google Ventures and I’ll explain:




The only part of the Google Ventures homepage that needs to be content managed is the Here’s what we’ve been up to  section. The header, the main photograph, the copy and the menu have all been carefully thought about by UX designer. All the elements work together in harmony and by allowing a content editor to take control over them you would risk the integrity of the site’s visual hierarchy, which would make it ugly and more difficult for the user to scan.

If the designer of Google Ventures was told that a content editor would be able to change the photo and add menu items, he/she may have designed it in a very different way, taking a more modular approach to mitigate against unknown future changes - much like you see on cheap, out-of-the-box themes. Flexibility is the enemy of interesting design.

Apple’s product pages are not content managed (See this one for the iPhone 5). Every image and every piece of copy has been carefully chosen. The design relies on the content not changing. Quality design like this doesn’t come out of a content managed website build.

The whole point of employing a designer is to present information in a fresh and easy to navigate way. Letting content editors make these choices is like letting a child plan their own meal - they think they know what they like but it always ends with sick on the floor.

So, how can we have strong, original design whilst letting content editor post great content? I think the key to decide on what pages are likely to change (or have new versions of them made) at least once a month (e.g. blog) and design these accordingly. For other pages, such as an about us page, which may only change once every six months, a better solution would be to hard code these pages in HTML and contract the designer/developer to change them when necessary.

As someone commissioning a new website, it’s tempting to think that you need a site you can completely control for the next two or three years and only speak to the developer when something breaks. The reality is that you’ll never be able to predict how you’ll use the site in the future and having an on going relationship with an agency that can respond to your needs over time makes much more sense - both financially and in terms of usability. Making every single element of a content managed web page is expensive and not cost effective, as most of those elements will probably never change. 

Think twice before trying to future-proof your website with an infinite number of features. Build lightly, focus on what you really need to control and work closely with your designer and developer to create sites with real impact, rather than just flexibility.
fields.intro: Why web agencies should do more than just handover a set of templates.

fields.body:
The map is an engaging way into the Global Competitiveness Index. Designed to be embedded, it will automatically centre itself on your country of location. We built it as part of a programme we are working on with WEF to help drive links and traffic to the Global Competitiveness Report and it is doing just that.

And it will carry on delivering. As Fernando Zarur, Associate Director of Digital Content at WEF, puts it:

"This sort of content is a way to explore the long-tail potential of our publications, working as channels of continuous interaction that can be maintained and updated year after year, extend sharing, benefitting SEO and hopefully making our different web channels grow in relevance."

The visualisation uses mapping services from Mapbox.com and some custom code largely reliant on Mustache.

Mapbox.com provided the key ingredients:

  • Tilemill: a desktop application for creating and styling map tiles and merging geo-spacial data
  • Mapbox hosting: a worldwide network of servers which serve up your tiles from the nearest data centre to your users
  • Mapbox.js: a javascript library for adding the maps to your html and adding the fancy bells and whistles

Tilemill is the real story here. It's a powerful tool used to add layers of data to a map of the world. Tilemill comes with some well-featured examples, but without your own dataset of points/shapes to display, its purpose is less clear.

Your data has to be provided in some specific formats (SQLite, PostGIS or Shape files) which require some work in themselves, but these can also be generated by other freely available third party tools. We used the country boundary lines shape files provided free by Natural Earth and combined the Competitiveness data from WEF using QGIS, a cross-platform desktop cartography program.

Once the data is imported, you can completely customise the visual style using CartoCSS, a language with a syntax closely resembling LESSCSS, in which individual points, countries, cities, streets, their labels etc can be customised to suit your preferred colour scheme. Using just a handful of lines of CartoCSS, we colour coded each of the countries based on it's rank in the Competitiveness Index.

Our custom code uses the Mustache templating language to display the raw Competitiveness data in a popup when you click on one of the countries.

Mapbox also curate some other projects we had less time to play with which are worth further investigation:

  • The MBTiles specification: a standard for graphical tile and data storage in SQLite databases,
  • Wax: a javascript "gateway" providing a standard way to add functionality and features provided by other third party Javascript map libraries, to maps from sources such as google, openstreetmap etc as well as mapbox.com themselves.
fields.intro: Each year, the brilliant folk at the World Economic Forum (WEF) create a Global Competitiveness Index "providing insight into the drivers of their productivity and prosperity". This post tells how we built them a map visualisation of the Index, which has featured on the Guardian, Economist, LA Times, Chicago Tribune and more.

fields.body:
#1 Start fast

Get on with it, don't spend time telling your audience what an honour and privilege it is to be talking to them, you're taking the wind out of your own sails.

#2 Know your audience

Why? So you can to pitch it right: you can personalise it, you can address their challenges, you can understand what will benefit them and you can use examples that are relevant. It'll be more interesting that way.

#3 Tell a story

People don't remember slides they remember stories. You want your presentation to fit together like a good story. Stories and examples are what great presentations are made from.

#4 Slides come last

Develop the story first. Write it down (as a speech, not an essay), storyboard it on paper, and only then do the slides.

#5 Start with a headline

Think of Steve Jobs: "Today Apple is going to reinvent the phone!". Headlines are memorable, they send a powerful message. And, use headlines on slides too. Steve didn't have a picture of the MacBook Air with the one word 'Thin', he had one with the headline 'The World's Thinnest Notebook'.

#6 Tell them what's coming

It helps the audience to follow your thread, and limit it to four main points. Guy Kawasaki likens this to your elevator pitch, but for many it's more like an outline of your talk. [Guy also has a 10, 20, 30 rule for entrepreneurs pitching their companies: 10 slides, in twenty minutes, and no font smaller than 30 points].

#7 One word note prompts

Distill your speech down into one word prompts. Start with it written out in full, then break it down into the key points, and then reduce those key points into one word prompts. If you are well rehearsed, one word prompts are all you need.

#8 Bullets can kill

Bullets can kill a presentation dead. Use bullets and your audience will read ahead rather than listen to you. You then become redundant, and boring. Alternatively, as Seth Godin has said, bullets are like an announcement for people to take notes, and if they start writing, they aren't listening properly. Use metaphorical photos or Twitter like headlines instead.

#9 Tease, don't tell

Get them interested first, don't just come straight out with it.

"An online video called 'The Girl Effect' starts by recounting a list of global problems: AIDS. Hunger. Poverty. War. Then, it asks, What if there was an unexpected solution to this mess? Would you even know it if you saw it? The solution isn’t the Internet. It’s not science. It’s not government. Curious? See, it works."

from Making your presentation stick by Chip and Dan Heath.

#10 Flow man, flow

Your presentation should flow. You want it to link together naturally like a good speech. To make your slides flow together well, prepare segueys between slides.

#11 The 10 minute rule

People get bored after ten minutes and lose attention. So, if you are going to be presenting for more than ten minutes, do something to break things up after ten minutes.

#12 To break it up...

Use some props, do a demo, show a video, get the audience involved in some way (make up a game perhaps). David Ogilvy in a board meeting once gave out a Russian doll to each attendee. They opened the dolls, bringing out smaller and smaller dolls, and wrapped around the smallest was a note:

"If we hire people who are smaller than we are, we shall become a company of dwarfs. If we hire people who are bigger than we are, we shall become a company of giants.”

No one forgot that message, the dolls saw to that.

#13 Get into it

Have fun, put something into it. People respond well to people who are engaged. Aristotle said that good speakers must have passion for the subject. Stand up, move around, gesticulate. Emotion works too.

#14 Finish with a flourish

Don't drift off into questions. Leave them something to remember you by. If you are in a pitch environment, if you don't finish memorably, there's less of a chance that your presentation will stand out in the memory from the others.

#15 Practice, practice, practice

If you are walking along the street mock-delivering your presentation over and over again in a low voice, you are not a mad person talking to themselves, you are a rational person about to deliver a brilliant presentation. Practice makes you good. 

References: 

  • The Presentation Secrets of Steve Jobs - Carmine Gallo
  • Writing that Works - Roman & Raphaelson
  • Making your presentation stick - Chip & Dan Heath

fields.body:
By default, Drupal installs with a robots.txt file in the root. For those of us that use the robotstxt module, one of the installation steps is to delete this file. This allows Drupal to handle the HTTP request and it allows site administrators to manage the contents of their robots file through the admin interface.

When you’re rolling out automated deployments of entire Drupal sites the last thing you want to do is have to delete that file each and every time. There are a few potential solutions to this problem - perhaps a post-install process to tidy up the file - but we opted to submit a patch into the robotstxt module’s issue queue. This patch adds a rewrite rule into the .htaccess file that always ensures Drupal handles requests for robots.txt. This means we don’t have to delete the robots.txt file and can deploy/redeploy sites that use robotstxt safely.

The patch affects a file that is part of Drupal core and while we’re aware this is normally something to avoid, we have a really specific requirement and the patch is part of an automated process. This means we can easily take it out and redeploy the entire build when a more suitable solution is available.
