Living Proof is ONE’s inspiring showcase of stories that demonstrate how foreign aid transforms the lives of some of the world’s poorest people. The website offers a powerful rebuke to criticisms of the ineffectual nature of foreign aid. We worked with ONE on the first iteration of the site.

With a more journalistic tone than the rest of Greenpeace's work, Energydesk focuses on open data, discussion, and reporting on energy and climate change. To fit with this approach, we wanted a clean, crisp, and simple design, with the Greenpeace branding a little less prominent.


By building this as a new child theme in Greenpeace's existing site, we've been able to keep things simple - existing content can be referenced easily from the new microsite, and new content is created using the existing workflows and processes that Greenpeace's staff are familiar with.

fields.body:
We’ve worked with the Waste and Resources Action Programme (WRAP) since 2004. We redeveloped the UK-wide site wrap.org.uk in Drupal. This single Drupal instance also underpins the various national waste and resources sites: Zero Waste Scotland, WRAP Cymru and WRAP Northern Ireland. Our work has spanned many projects including their primary website and the Love Food Hate Waste and Recycle Now consumer campaigns.

Love Food Hate Waste

Torchbox have been closely involved in the Love Food Hate Waste campaign since its inception in 2007. During this time we worked with WRAP to deliver both the main Love Food Hate Waste website along with animations, competitions and portion planning tools.


Beginning with the design and Drupal build, our work on Love Food Hate Waste has since included producing animations and infographics to help promote awareness about reducing food waste. We’ve also carried out search engine optimisation work on the site to ensure that its message – and extensive database of delicious recipes – reaches as many people as possible.



Recycle Now

Recycle Now is the national recycling campaign for England, supported and funded by Government, managed by WRAP and used locally by over 90% of English authorities. We developed a fresh, intuitive Drupal site that enables visitors to search for recycling outlets, read about the latest recycling tips and methods and engage with the crucial work RecycleNow is carrying out.

fields.intro: A suite of Drupal sites for long-term partners the Waste and Resources Action Programme

fields.body:
King's Fund wanted to document how health and social care issues were shaping the political landscape in the run up to the 2015 UK general election. They chose a micro-site powered by our new Django content management system, Wagtail, that showcased their content in a timeline format.


The project looked to engage users in the political debate around health and social care by a providing a platform that centralised the ongoing conversation. An important goal was to drive traffic to the main content on the King's website, as well as other sources from party websites and debates. The posts are treated as separate pages which allows for easy sharing via fully integrated social media. 

This one-page format is an interesting use of the Wagtail CMS and makes for a unique content structure. Users can browse by date or filter according to political party and the site is fully responsive for use on mobile.
fields.summary: A micro-site powered by Wagtail tracking events leading up to the 2015 UK general election

fields.body:
Chatham House engages governments, the private sector and civil society in open debate and confidential discussion on the most significant developments in international affairs. We were delighted to be commissioned to redevelop the Chatham House website as a platform for independent and rigorous analysis of critical global, regional and country-specific challenges.


We carried out the build on Drupal 7 using our existing framework for speed and performance. Major data migration was required to form a huge body of content (10,000+ nodes). The depth of the site presented an interesting challenge for navigation and information architecture. We worked closely with the Chatham team to design and implement a structure that served the complex needs of the organisation while maintaining a sleek and usable interface.

A particular achievement was our custom development on events functionality. We applied a views-based approach to run queries and filter events according to the various criteria of potential audiences (members, membership type, etc.). This custom development seamlessly integrated with the existing third-party membership database, EBMS.


One of the most enjoyable parts of the project was working with the Chatham House team. We achieved a collaborative, fluid approach that allowed us to think creatively and problem-solve setbacks. The result is a site that can comfortably and competently appeal to its primary audience of decision-makers and political influencers.

DataKind™ are a New-York based organisation who bring together data scientists and NGOs - in our world of data revolution, the geeks help the NGOs get something useful out of their data. Together they form a community of pioneering data scientists, visionary changemakers, community builders and social innovators. 

We rebuilt the DataKind  site using Mezzanine, an open source CMS built in Django. A powerful, consistent, and flexible content management platform, Mezzanine provides a simple and extensible architecture. 


Our designers worked directly in HTML and CSS to create a design for the site that allowed us to review working wireframes in the browser. The effect is elegant and clean.

We used Skype and our usual comms tools to bridge the ocean and ensure the project ran smoothly.

fields.body:
Photojournalist Brendan Bannon embarked on a writing and photography project with refugee children in Yemen and Namibia. Through a series of workshops, he taught young refugees how to frame the world from their unique perspective using a camera and to write about their images. Called “Do You See What I See?”, the project resulted in a photo essay seen by over 100,000 people on UNHCR’s Flickr site and physical exhibitions in Yemen, Namibia, Italy, Geneva and New York.


UNHCR commissioned us to build a website to showcase a new iteration of the project that saw Bannon encountering children who have fled the war in Syria and sought refugee in Jordan and Lebanon. UNHCR provided the designs, and we built and powered the site with our Wagtail Django CMS.


The site makes strong use of social media and share functionality, allowing visitors to easily share individual pieces of content. A particular achievement was the multi-language functionality; the site is available in Arabic as well as English, which presented an interesting challenge for readability.


The result is a visually striking and sophisticated site that lends itself to the hugely important and emotionally gripping content. Do you see what they see?
fields.summary: A glimpse into the lives of refugee children through a stunning website built on our Wagtail CMS
fields.intro:
A glimpse into the lives of refugee children through a stunning website built on our Wagtail CMS

Visit Do You See What I See?

fields.body:
Development

Situation Analysis - Where are we now? We want to get to know everything about you, your organisation and what you stand for. So get in touch and have a chat to one of our experts about what it is you are aspiring to achieve.

Objectives - Where do we want to be? We put the utmost importance in understanding where you want to be. We want to ensure that we can offer you the best help possible in order to make sure your organisation’s aspirations are met.

Strategy - How do we get there? Your organisation may be at any stage of development, we therefore offer a range of services, from creating completely new strategies, to enhancing and redeveloping your current strategies. We will have constant communication with you to ensure you and your business get to where you want to be.

Tactics - How exactly do we get there? We will utilise our extensive social media knowledge to devise and implement a strategy that works best to get your business to the level it should be at. Social Media marketing aims to engage, interact and monitor with potential consumers and we pride ourselves on being experts in these fields.

Actions - What is our plan? Our social media experts will work closely with you to develop and implement the strategy best suited to you and your organisation. You will be involved in all stages of the process to ensure your satisfaction is guaranteed.

Control - Did we get there? Success is not just about implementing a strategy, in order to have a successful partnership we will maintain constant communication and provide feedback on the development of your goals.


Training

We are constantly learning and developing our skills, and we aim to share everything we learn with you. We can offer a vast range of training through a number of different means. Throughout the world, we aim to teach individuals, small groups and teams. We can train you on the ways to most effectively manage and monitor social media platforms. Similarly we aim to show you how to efficiently run social media advertising campaigns.

fields.body:
What did we set out to achieve?

We had two Key Performance Indicators (KPI): The number of referrals (clicks) per month and the number of Likes, Comments and Shares (Engagements). Whilst our main objective was to drive traffic to Yahoo UK’s sports content, we were also tasked with establishing an active and engaged audience.

We also set ourselves the challenge of seeing month-of-month improvements in clicks.

Developing an editorial

Our first step was to bring our experience and knowledge of the Edgerank algorithm to our posting style. We knew that a post had 'edges' based upon the 'affinity' between the page and it's fans, the 'weight' of the type of post and the time decay factor

So, we developed three principles for every post.

  • Intrigue
  • Timeliness
  • Engaging

Putting every single detail of a story into a Facebook post is not the best way to drive referrals. An article can have plenty of detail but the update has to summarize a couple of the key points and leave some for the reader to find out. Ideally, a Facebook post is somewhere between a headline and a lede.

It’s not a surprise that breaking news will have a greater impact than old news, so we would always try to be one of the first to get updates out with a big story, or to tactically post update during the peak times people would be on Facebook.

We would try to insert a call-to-action wherever we could. This was mostly in the form of asking a question and gathering the opinions of the users. This was ideal when there was a hot topic of conversation

The content


We had to drive referrals to any page on https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com, a sports page run in partnership between Eurosport and Yahoo. This included constantly updated, blog post, features and video content as well as access to image libraries.

Keeping Track

One of the most important lessons was to keep track of our efforts and to give ourselves daily updates. This way, we could review what is working, what can be improved and if there were any surprises. We never allowed our tracking of results to become complacent. We calculated exactly how many referrals per day we needed in order to beat our targets.

Using tracking codes, Bitly links and analysing Facebook insights, we could provide precise stats of our efforts

Always Growing

This graph demonstrates the growth of the page over three years. The vast majority of this growth was organic with under 1,000 coming from paid adverts. 

The reason behind this growth is down to us constantly re-evaluating, making changes to our editorial and paying very close attention to any changes to Facebook’s algorithm. There were several times, most noticeably the end of 2013, that the page was very highly valued in Edgerank terms so the page’s reach dramatically increase. This in turn brought more fans of our content to like the page.

There were over 2.5 millions Likes, Comments and Shares over these three years, and we keep getting more each month.

Doing More

As our relationship with Yahoo UK developed and our successes became greater, we were in prime positions to help with other tasks as well as take on other responsibilities. This includes assisting in ad spend, writing reports on 30 Yahoo Facebook pages, running Twitter accounts, creating Tumblr themes, managing Tumblr accounts and creating strategy documents.

We hope to continue our long and prosperous relationship with Yahoo UK.

The response from Yahoo UK

"QUOTE TBC."


- Richard Blake, Head of UK Marketing, Yahoo

Now, the page has 450,000 fans and beat 1.5 million referrals in July 2014

fields.body:
What did we set out to achieve?

We were asked to develop the concept and build an interactive digital element to raise awareness of the school governor role and encourage people to volunteer. Additionally, we planned and implemented a digital campaign to circulate it to as wide an audience as possible. The target, based on the success of previous campaigns, was to generate 75 applications.

Developing a theme

We immersed ourselves into the world of the school governor. We searched a lot and we read a lot. We learnt that school governors make really important decisions like appointing  a head teacher and setting the school’s aims and budget, but that the public were largely unaware of this. 

We felt the key to recruiting new governors was showing the public how important the role is, the sort of decisions that governors make, and that there are openings available.

The theme for our campaign was: ‘Could you be a School Maker?’.

The compelling content

We wanted to bring the role to life in an entertaining and cost effective way. We did this by developing an interactive video using Rapt Media’s platform. Three children formed an interview panel and asked users what they would do in situations school governors face – for example whether to sell off part of the school field in order to be able to replace IT facilities. Users would be able to choose what they would do and the children would act out the consequences. 

Friends and family

The production of the video really was a Torchbox affair! The actors in the video are two of Olly Willans’ (our Creative Director) children and one of their friends and it was shot at a local school where Tom Dyson (our Tech Director) is a governor! The video was shot by Ross Harrison - the son of Susan (our Financial Manager). 

You can watch the final piece here: www.sgoss.org.uk/schoolmakers.html

‘The latest initiative from SGOSS is the School Makers campaign, which saw the launch of  a new, and rather brilliant, interactive video campaign.’ Peter Henshaw, Editor, SecEd

Making it famous

We were excited about the video and wanted the world to know about it!

A PR campaign focused on survey results showing the lack of knowledge about the decisions school governors make and encouraged people to apply for vacancies. Widespread coverage was received on national, regional and online media such as Radio 2, Radio 4, Radio 5 Live, over 20 regional BBC stations and the BBC website. 

To give the campaign a further boost, SGOSS arranged for promotions to be secured with partners such as Aviva, Deutsche Bank, Lloyds TSB and Teach First.

The content was also well received on social platforms and a Thunderclap promotion gave people the chance to donate a Facebook post or Tweet to support the campaign.


Watch Rob Salmon’s talk on School Makers from ECF 2014.

The results

We were to be judged on the number of applications received and the campaign completely surpassed expectations.

The target number of applications was 75. 

The campaign delivered 804, beating the target by 972%.

The response from SGOSS

"All our carefully thought out and realistic targets based on previous campaign data were smashed within 36 hours of launch. We couldn’t have achieved this without the great work from Torchbox."

- Christopher Parker, Head of Marketing & Communications, SGOSS
fields.summary: Beating the target by 972%
fields.intro: When SGOSS asked us to help them recruit new school governors, we focused on raising awareness of the vital role they undertake, in a fun and interactive way. The results surpassed all expectations.

fields.body:
Actually, HRH, the Prince of Wales, launched the site, while welcoming in a new era for the school as it changed from the Prince’s Drawing School to the Royal Drawing School.


The Royal Drawing School is a cool, inspirational place (it's got me drawing more and encouraging my family to draw as well). We wanted to do justice to this fantastic institution without resorting to flashiness, and I think we’ve achieved that. 


The site mixes quiet restraint with splashes of bold colour, and showcases thousands of stunning drawings alongside the profiles of hundreds of staff, students and alumni. And, it builds successfully on the lovely, new branding work by John Morgan Studio with its distinctive, custom version of Monokrom's Vinter typeface.


Best of all, however, it brings the experience of the school and the opportunities it offers to life and makes it easy to join in. Whether it be the one year drawing master’s, one of the many public courses offered at five studios around London (and out and about: Drawing at the National Gallery next week, anyone?), or the programmes for children, it’s now much easier to find what you want - whatever device you access the site on (obviously).


We very much wanted to work with the school and were very happy to have won through the pitch process (in no small part thanks to our experience and work with the Royal College of Art). And, I’m very proud of what we have delivered and the team that has delivered it, marshalled by Chris Rogers, designed by Wes West, and with Dan Braghis leading the development.

fields.body:
Racking up close to a million visitors every year, the Roman Baths is easily one of the most popular tourist attractions in the South West. The nearby Fashion Museum has similar standing as one of the foremost in the world, housing a rare collection of Georgian costumes and featuring the ‘dress of the year’. Not many people know both venues are both governed by the Bath & North East Somerset Council Heritage Services (BANES).

Our brief was to design a set of sites for the BANES venues, each with a compelling and distinct digital presence that remained part of a clear family. BANES were keen to promote their connection with the tourist hotspots of their beloved city. Other less well-known venues would be promoted alongside more popular ones, such as the Roman Baths. 

One of our first concepts was the ‘site picker’ - featuring a strip of site logos that lets the user choose their desired venue. Once selected, each site changes in colour and content while retaining the same layout. Design-wise, we wanted to convey a sense of place, incorporating the wonderful imagery on offer. Our hope was to inspire potential visitors as well as give them everything they needed to plan their visit.


We carried out user testing on actual visitors we managed to collar in the queue for the Roman Baths and asked them to complete a series of tasks while we recorded audio, video and mouse movement - turns out plug sockets are a little hard to access in Victorian wood-panelled meeting rooms...

Feedback suggested that we needed to give even greater prominence to our ‘site picker’, so we worked on getting the wording exactly right, checking in with our Google expert who recommendedOther things to do as the key phrase for those searching online.

The result: an elegantly designed family of sites to suitably promote Bath’s cultural treasures.

fields.body:
What did we set out to achieve?

In 2000, the UN launched a fifteen year plan called the Millennium Development Goals. In September 2014, the UN’s General Assembly gathered to discuss plans for the next 15 years.


In the run-up to this meeting, International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) launched the #IDECIDE campaign, the objective of which was to gather support for putting sexual and reproductive rights at the heart of the UN’s economic, environmental and social development agenda.


  • 220m women in the developing world want contraception but can’t get it.

  • Currently 1 in 3 women has experienced violence

  • Every year 47,000 women die of unsafe abortions.

  • An estimated 67 million girls are married before their 18th birthday


This campaign was a multi-layered approach that also included a Facebook campaign, YouTube videos, several promoted tweets and a billboard in New York’s Times Square, all of which lead to encourage signatures on the petition. One of the stars in this campaign was the Lead-Generation Tweet, which meant that people could sign the petition from within Twitter itself.

The Tweet

There are many things to consider in order to get the best possible results from a promoted campaign on Twitter. Optimising every aspect from the language to the targeting is important as it’s very simple for small changes to against what is best practice. This was the Tweet that was sent out at the height of the IPPF activity.

It was promoted using what we felt was the best possible targeting and we monitored it throughout the day, making small alterations to the ad spend .


Every user who clicked the blue “Sign the petition” button, their Registered name, Email and Twitter Handle was saved. This could then be exported automatically to a number of CRM programs or exported as a CSV file.

Repeat Success


On 11 October, we ran the campaign again to coincide with International Day of the Girl, a UN designated day to bring these issues to the forefront. Building on what we had learned in the previous campaign, we ran a similar campaign and changed the wording to reflect the day.


Next Steps

The people who clicked the petitions were added to a list and sent a thank you Email for their involvement in the #IDECIDE Twitter campaign. The Email was personalised with their Twitter handle and contained more information and further calls-to-action. This is a great list as they could be called upon to support Twitter-based campaign in the future.


The Results

These Twitter promoted campaigns had 1,875 ReTweets, created 742 new followers and  generated 3,006 Email leads that were added to the petition.


The benchmark for Average Engagement Rate for Promoted Tweets is about 1%. These Lead Generation Tweets managed an average of 1.93% with one Tweet managing 2.43%!

Based upon the entire spend on promoting the Tweets, the average cost-per-lead (CPL) of about around £0.89. One campaign even managed to get as low as £0.45!

The response from International Planned Parenthood Federation


QUOTE TBC
fields.summary: Less than £1 Cost-per-Lead (CPL) for non-profits

Advertising goals

Optimization

Grantspro

Google Third-Party Policy

fields.summary: A full site redevelopment on Wagtail with an ambitious, health charity that punches well above its weight, including Salesforce integration.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Meningitis Now came to us as an ambitious health charity that punches hard for their weight.\u00a0They recognised that they needed to totally overhaul their digital offering and got boldly on board with Wagtail; specifying a sophisticated, extensible CRM integration (we built the Salesforce integration onto Wagtail), and took a clear focus on mobile.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Simple, clear pages. Stress free and easy to understand, prioritising the common use case and guiding users to action.", "image": 404, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The previous site was somewhat overwhelming, particularly the navigation. It didn\u2019t serve the standard use cases as well as it might. And, it didn\u2019t work well on mobile. \u00a0The bounce rate and single session levels are very high because the most common use case is people checking signs and symptoms of meningitis in a potential emergency.

"}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Our UX process"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In consultation with internal staff and users (including being invited to the Houses of Commons to meet some of their key supporters over tea and french fancies), we employed our user modelling process to quickly identify personas, needs, and user journeys.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "We identified all the desired actions and created action snippets that can be added to pages by editors.", "image": 484, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our process is about delivering on user needs but also delivering to organisational objectives so we identified the actions that we want people to complete and created a Wagtail snippet for each of the actions. Editors are now able to add the most context relevant CTA at the end of any page.\u00a0

And stories of people are placed at the heart of the experience, we use these as an additional way to expose the fantastic services that the charity offers to support people who have had or are experiencing meningitis.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Follow-on actions and content drive interactions.", "image": 402, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Design philosophy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We set out to to deliver a strong brand experience but without allowing the brand to overwhelm the content. And the site achieves this.\u00a0

The design is particularly strong on mobile as befits a site where 75% of the visits are now on mobile!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Very high mobile access rates reflect the high volumes of people wanting to quickly check the symptoms of meningitis.", "image": 401, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The site immediately looks uncluttered and straightforward, which is what you need, especially if you are faced with the terrifying prospect of needing to confirm the symptoms of meningitis. The navigation has been hugely reduced and simplified, as has the number of items visible at any one time.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "Wagtail is fast and simple for teams to create stunning websites. The interface is intuitive and the language used means non-technical people can use it with ease. You can even edit from your mobile in emergencies.", "attribution": "Richard Hudson Director of Digital & Marketing"}}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Integration"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In parallel to the website redevelopment, Meningitis Now were also introducing a new Salesforce CRM with which the site integrates. Though not our first time integrating Salesforce, this was the first time we have integrated it with Wagtail. We specified, built and delivered a Wagtail integration that captures, backs up and posts to Salesforce all submissions made through Wagtail. \u00a0

Using Wagtail's Formbuilder we delivered a flexible form creation system that allows Meningitis Now to create any kind of form and capture any kind of data request (e.g. contact information, support request, multiple choice questions, etc.) into Salesforce. It offers a robust and scalable approach to Salesforce CRM integration.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Salesforce integration allows Meningitis Now can easily set up new, Salesforce connected forms using Wagtail's form builder", "image": 403, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Review"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

While the single visit rate and bounce rate are still high as you would expect, the site now has\u00a0

  • 50% more repeat visitors than this time last year.\u2028
  • Mobile usage up to almost 75% against a national average of 30%, and this is driving significant growth in traffic.\u2028
  • Organic search referrals up 58% and in the last two months page views are up almost 40% on last year.\u2028

And people are completing more actions on the site too.\u2028

We are proud of a focused and effective site and have enjoyed every moment of working with Meningitis Now.


"}]

fields.summary: We help bring corruption to light with a new, re-imagined, Wagtail-powered website for the undercover investigators and campaigners, Global Witness.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

When fellow agency, Mark Boulton Design (MBD) were acquired by Monotype, Global Witness, were in the early stages of working with them on their site redevelopment. They were forced to go looking for a new digital agency. Happily, they chose Torchbox.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

That suited us. Global Witness are a fantastic organisation. They do undercover, investigative journalism into some of the dodgiest companies and regimes in the world. And they campaign to change the system and to lift the resource curse that condemns millions of people to lives of poverty and violence. Just the sort of thing that we want to help with.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "A topic page on the new GlobalWitness.org, shown on laptop and mobile", "image": 488, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

First stop, finish the discovery. We built on the MBD audience research by running a user modelling workshop where we:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Broke down the audiences into seventeen types (including groups from developing countries who weren\u2019t really represented in the three crystallised personas)\u00a0
  • Developed quick personas for each audience type\u00a0
  • Identified triggers and contexts for visits for each quick persona\u00a0
  • Identified needs for each persona\u00a0
  • Mapped the possible actions that each persona might want to complete on that visit [this connects the user objectives with an organisations objectives].\u00a0

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "Our new website is a central part of our plans for the future, and we are very pleased with its performance so far. Torchbox delivered on a demanding and wide-ranging brief, which included the need to improve our storytelling abilities at the same time as migrate a huge archive of complex and varied material across from our old site. We are pleased with progress against both of these objectives so far, and see real potential for further development within the Wagtail system. ", "attribution": "Oliver Courtney, Global Witness"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Armed with what we had learnt from this session, we could ground our creative ideas in the real needs of the audiences and it helped Global Witness\u00a0to believe in the process. Further sessions on digital principles, objectives, creative positioning and scoping followed.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Early design for the report page on GlobalWitness.org", "image": 487, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Gradually, we honed a vision for the site:

  • It needed to grab you, \u00a0particularly the non-specialist audiences. It had to be more like an online magazine than an academic research repository.
  • We didn\u2019t want to hide the fact that there is loads of depth to the content, so we needed a sense of layering of content: easy to absorb stuff first with quick access to the detail and archives
  • The current, key campaigns had to real stand out, setting the current agenda\u00a0
  • We needed to extend visit length
  • While they started using Shorthand on our recommendation to bring their stories to life, we wanted to be able to make great report pages without needing to use Shorthand.
  • Previously they had often built report and campaign pages as static micro-sites, as their main site wasn't flexible enough. We wanted to give them the flexibility and creative power within the CMS so that they didn't have to create additional static sites.

"}, {"type": "bustout", "value": {"text": "

One month after launch we achieved a\u00a0230% increase in users of the website, a\u00a050% increase in time\u00a0on site, a\u00a012% decrease in bounce rate, and a\u00a0fourfold increase in click throughs via organic Google searches.

", "image": 492}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The result is a revitalised, smart, engaging site. The incredible content shines through, and it keeps on coming. And the whole site, is enhanced by some neat interaction design. Here are a few stand out elements of what we have done:

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "The slide up navigation includes priority campaigns and countries", "image": 486, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • The new CMS, Wagtail is the engine behind the site.
  • The striking, \u2018drop-up\u2019 navigation emphasises the priority projects.
  • Alongside the promoted content on each subject area, users can use the scrolling left column to dive into the complete archive of content on that subject from detailed reports and press releases selected tweets.
  • Self-retracting menus leave maximum space for dramatic, full screen presentation of the stories
  • Wagtail\u2019s Streamfield allows for dramatic and flexible storytelling
  • Security has had to be a focus - something that\u2019s already been tested by a number of hacking attempts, presumably by people who don\u2019t like what Global Witness are saying about them.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Check out the work at\u00a0https://www.globalwitness.org/.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": " Throughout the process Torchbox have been highly professional and enjoyable to work with, and they know their area inside out. We would recommend them highly.\u201d", "attribution": "Oliver Courtney, Global Witness"}}]

fields.summary: A new user-focussed Wagtail website for the UK's grocery charity.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

GroceryAid appointed us to rehaul their ageing website with a new responsive design built on the open source CMS Wagtail, integrated with their Oracle-based helpline system and Blackbaud event booking.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Integration with Blackbaud event booking has made events easier to administer", "image": 502, "attribution": "", "alignment": "right"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

GroceryAid provides help to people working in the grocery industry, looking after thousands of people with financial support, grants, free help and advice and a 24/7 helpline. The charity also runs many successful fundraising events around the UK \u2013 balls, sporting events, team challenges, and more.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Balancing user needs"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are very different groups of users: from people in desperate situations seeking support, to people looking to attend a lavish ball.

The existing website didn't cater well to the key use cases, with a sitemap that had grown over time and unclear routes through content. Neither did it clearly explain what GroceryAid does.

Our discovery process, including a user modelling workshop, helped to create a clear route through the site for the different groups of users, guiding them to take action.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "The new site directs different audiences into key sections - to get help, or to support the charity.", "image": 500, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Increasing engagement with calls-to-action"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The site features a reusable snippet\u00a0allowing editors to create a library of \"actions\" that can be added in relevant contexts around the site \u2013 so on the bottom of pages about applying for help, there's a prominent \"Contact the helpline\" action. Or on event pages, we're pointing visitors toward contacting the events team to sponsor fundraising events.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Prominent calls-to-action have led to increased conversion rate for key goals.", "image": 501, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "Torchbox managed a tricky brief, to work with existing databases and processes whilst improving the user experience and giving it \u2018wow\u2019 factor. Through their meticulous planning and execution we now have a website that looks a million times better than before and have already seen an increase in visits to previously unnoticed information.", "attribution": "Jenny Fryatt, Communications Manager, GroceryAid"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Integration and collaboration"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The GroceryAid Helpline is an Oracle-based CRM, so we worked closely with the helpline developers to make sure there are seamless transitions between the two systems:

  • a unified site search that lists both Wagtail and helpline content
  • a realtime header and footer to \"wrap\" around the helpline content
  • Google Tag Manager containers to track users between the domains

The integration means that GroceryAid editors can easily reference content from the helpline within Wagtail.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A few weeks on, and the results are starting to show:

  • Bounce rate down from 45% to 35%
  • Average visit duration up from 2:40 to 3:15
  • Average pages per session up from 3.4 to 4.4

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "We have thoroughly enjoyed our working relationship with Torchbox. Our new website is a testimony to their design talents and we have had so much positive feedback.", "attribution": "Cathy Mercer, Welfare Development Director, GroceryAid"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're really proud of the collaboration with GroceryAid on bringing a user-focussed approach to their digital work.

Check out the site at www.groceryaid.org.uk

"}]

fields.summary: Bringing grantmaking impact to life with stories and data visualisation.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We were really excited to design and build the Wagtail-powered website for The Children\u2019s Investment Fund Foundation (CIFF).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The new website is a key element in CIFF\u2019s drive for greater transparency in grant making, and to share what they and their partners are learning.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Demystifying the data"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The centrepiece is the\u00a0grant portfolio, an interactive visualisation of live grant data. It allows site visitors to browse grants via a dynamic set of bar charts representing grants by priority area, topic, and region \u2013 and then access the full detail about any particular grant.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Each time a grant page is updated, added or removed by an editor, the totals are recalculated and the bar chart updates.", "image": 496, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This live view across themes and geographies \u2013 previously unavailable, even to CIFF staff \u2013 is a really clear way to visualise the very large numbers involved. We focussed on keeping the interface simple and responsive across all devices from desktop to mobile.

Of course, there\u2019s a standard filterable listing available if you want to be more selective (want to see\u00a0nutrition grants in Africa?\u00a0Education grants in South Asia?)

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "We wanted a flexible and intuitive content management system\u2026 a simple yet sophisticated site which champions the use of data and evidence\u2026 an adaptable tool to help us embrace transparency in everything we do. Using Wagtail, the Torchbox team has helped design and build an exciting platform which has the potential to help us achieve all of these goals.", "attribution": "James Whittington, Director of Communications"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The site is also one of the first outings for Wagtail\u2019s\u00a0StreamField feature.\u00a0StreamField is used on the \u201cinsight\u201d pages to give a rich, flexible content layout for CIFF\u2019s editors to tell the story of what they\u2019re learning from key programmes, and bring the data to life.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Including videos, responsive chart embeds from Highcharts, interactive maps from CartoDB all created by the client \u2013 no problem with StreamField.", "image": 497, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Without measurement we are guessing"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As with the majority of our projects we\u2019re using Google Analytics \u2013 in this case, to report on how people are using the grant portfolio and on the range of on-site conversions such as signing up to email, viewing key pages and documents, sharing content or following key staff on social media.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "bustout", "value": {"text": "

After launch, sessions were up by\u00a050%, bounce rate down by\u00a07%, and average duration up\u00a015%\u00a0- a more engaged audience, with increased conversion rate for all goals.

", "image": 499}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With a client so focussed on data and evidence for their grantmaking work, it goes without saying that we'll be using the analytics to continue to enhance the site over time.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Check out the website at\u00a0ciff.org\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: These are services

Wes comes from a background in film-making and animation and spent several years working on commercials and music videos in Soho.
fields.biography:
As well as directing Torchbox's animation and video work, he leads on many of our creative content and data projects.

Wes has a growing interest in behavioural psychology, which feeds nicely into his design and UX work. He was the brains behind our successful Christmas iPad video, Starry night, and the person responsible for setting up an internet powered snow machine in the office.

Outside of work he loves walking, camping, travel and trips to the beach.

fields.intro: Christopher studied English at Hertford College, Oxford and developed an obsession with James Joyce.
fields.biography:
He joined Torchbox as a project manager but now specializes in PPC, Google Analytics and SEO. He has a growing side interest in A/B testing. He is Google AdWords and Analytics certified and manages Google Ad Grants for our charity clients. He loves taking these accounts up to the Grantspro level ($40,000 a month of free advertising). 

In his spare time he drums in samba bands, plays the ukulele and enjoys cycling and wild swimming.

fields.intro: Dave has been with Torchbox since 2001 and specialises in absorbing knowledge from a wide range of both front and back end disciplines.
fields.biography:
He currently leads the Front End team, keeping the rest of Torchbox up to scratch with front end technologies. 

Dave leads on the interaction design and front end development for Wagtail, our open-source Django-based CMS.

fields.intro: Edward joined Torchbox in 2008, so has broad experience in working with many of our clients.
fields.biography: Although his passion lies in project management, coming from a development background he's able to fully understand the technical details. Edward introduced Kanban and feature-driven development to Torchbox and now heads up both our Drupal and project management teams. Outside work he's a keen runner and is usually planning a holiday to some far-flung destination.

He tries to code and do front end,

His skill is neat, his eye is keen,

A broken site his craft will mend,

It's such a shame he makes us scream

fields.intro: Ian has been taking care of new business at Torchbox since 2002.
fields.biography:
Winning new work takes time, and Ian wants to win. So identifying the best and most interesting opportunities that fit with our values, skills and approach, and ensuring we respond with compelling proposals and sparkling pitches, is his thing.

A voracious consumer of technology news and much more besides, Ian likes to relax by running 400m, travelling with his family, playing tennis, and enjoying fine food and wine, but not necessarily in that order.

fields.intro: Olly is a Founder Director and the Creative Director at Torchbox. His job is to help our clients achieve fantastic things online.
fields.biography:
He is ultimately responsible for the design, digital strategy, user experience, and information architecture work at Torchbox. Along with Tom, Olly also fulfils the role of MD at Torchbox.

Olly has led our teams creating award-winning sites and campaigns for a roll-call of the most exciting organisations in the development, health and education sectors. Olly tries to ensure that Torchbox doesn't just meet expectations in our projects, but exceeds them. And, after fifteen years, Olly is just as excited about the Internet's potential as a force for social good as he was in the first dot com days.

Olly leads on our user experience team and is hands on in several UX projects, running workshops, defining IAs, co-creating wireframes, overseeing test programmes, as well as running a programme of ongoing development to ensure that our UX practices are continually evolving.

Olly is a married dad of three. He enjoys sports (cycling, skiing, tennis, cricket, squash), and dabbles with am-dram! He is currently rehearsing for a much anticipated role as the Sheriff of Nottingham, in the Northmoor Village pantomime. To the shame of his son and father-in-law, Olly is only a half-hearted Manchester United supporter.

Olly is Non-Executive Director of the charity Valid Nutrition.

fields.intro: Tom is a co-founder of Torchbox, and its Technical Director.
fields.biography:
Tom graduated from Balliol College, Oxford, in 1995, swapping the later philosophy of Wittgenstein for Netscape 2 and a 9600 baud modem. He ran a little agency called Naïve ("Why don't you just call yourselves 'Stupid'?") until he joined forces with Olly in 2000, starting Torchbox with the aim of building beautiful online software for people who make the world a better place.

As Technical Director, Tom is responsible for making sure the things we build are fast and reliable and easy to maintain. He manages the tech team and account directs many of our large technical projects. Along with Olly, Tom tries to make Torchbox a fun and inspiring place to work.

Tom lives with his family in the countryside. He reads novels and gets cross at tennis. He plays in three bands who will probably never make it. He composed the theme tune to Charlie and Lola.

fields.intro: Ben has been designing websites for Torchbox since 2004.
fields.biography:
He has been responsible for some of our standout creative work, including the WWF global redesign and WWF UK fundraising site, The King’s Fund, Canal & River Trust, Digital Science, the UK Green Building Council and Chatham House.

Now based in our Bristol wing, he has recently lead the design for Bath Heritage Services, and the new Wagtail sites for both Meningitis NOW and Global Witness.

Outside of work he loves to brew and is perfecting his thrice-hopped pale ale. He’s also a savoury chap and loves a Bovril.

fields.intro: Johan joined Torchbox in 2011.
fields.biography:
He's a firm believer in giving users as much control of their site as they can reasonably manage and while he's most at home working with APIs and custom code, you'll also find him working alongside our designers to implement the latest cutting edge designs.

Occasionally found at local user groups or events talking about moving data or sharing it between disparate systems in a meaningful way, Johan is always interested in ways to reduce the less interesting or repetitive parts of projects. As part of Team Drupal at Torchbox, he'll also be found contributing code patches, issues and support on drupal.org and interesting technical snippets/topics on Team Drupal's tumblr.

Outside of work, you can normally find him planning an adventurous holiday, tending to his tropical fish or ploughing his way through a recent box set series.

Favourite animal: Toss up between Bumphead Parrotfish or Blue-footed Booby.

Favourite cheese: Reblochon.

Favourite place: Koh Tao, Thailand.

fields.intro: Helen studied English at university, but discovered her inner geek via a postgraduate course in Cartography.
fields.biography:
Helen studied English at Keble College, Oxford and took a postgraduate diploma in Cartography at Oxford Brookes.

Before joining Torchbox in 2004 she worked variously as a cartographer, a web developer and a programmer on an ESA project. Previously she was developer and project manager for many RationalMedia sites, but she now works as a front end developer on various Drupal and wagtail sites, including Oxford University and the Royal College of Art.

Outside work her main job is being a mum, but she also enjoys reading, singing in the Charlbury community choir, growing organic vegetables and attempting the Saturday Guardian crossword.

fields.intro: Justine has been meddling with Drupal's theming layer since 2009. She helps to coordinate Frontend United - the annual Drupal Frontend conference and she regularly volunteers at Drupal events.
fields.biography:
Justine has led the Front End development of several of our Drupal projects including Recycle Now and Chatham House.

Outside of work she loves to forage for anything edible in the countryside and is perfecting her cider-making skills. She also likes to change her hair colour to match her outfits.

fields.intro: Rob is our digital marketing specialist who loves it when a plan comes together.
fields.biography: Rob loves to wax lyrical about the merits of creating compelling content and making that content famous. This is what he aimed for with the award-winning Carling programme that he led at Molson Coors where he worked on 'iPint' - one of the UK's most popular iPhone apps. Rob loves to work up a good plan and then go on about 'making it happen'. He sits on the IAB's Social Media Council and is a former Chair of ISBA's Digital Action Group. If you fancy a curry, a pint, a good natter about football and a sing song, then head to Rob's house!

fields.intro: Chris joined Torchbox in July 2013 with a background in digital publishing in the academic and trade sectors.
fields.biography:
After completing a Masters degree in Publishing at Oxford Brookes, Chris spent the next three years hovering around Oxford University Press, working in a variety of digital roles from user testing English Language Training CDs for the South American market on obscure Linux distributions to project managing the updates to the online edition of the Oxford Textbook of Medicine, a gargantuan tome in three volumes featuring over 300 authors and 600 chapters.

He then moved on to trade publishing, wrangling ebooks and ebook retailers as Digital Publishing Technology Coordinator for Penguin Books in London.

Since joining Torchbox, Chris has worked with a range of clients including The Royal College of Art, Global Witness, The King's Fund, and the Internet Society.

In his spare time, Chris is a skateboarder of sixteen years experience and a guitarist of three.

fields.intro: Glenn hails from New Zealand, having lived in Australia and South Africa along the way, and has been living in the UK since 1994.
fields.biography:
He has been a full time web developer since the mid-noughties, although launched his first commercial site in 2001.

Glenn enjoys traction kiting, BBQing, games and sport, including coaching a local youth football team.

Based in Bristol, Glenn is part of our new office's team.

fields.intro: Dan is a noble <table>-fighter, knight of <div> and order from the picturesque country of Moldova.
fields.biography:
A graduate of the American University of Bulgaria with a degree in Computer Science and Information Technology, Dan oversees the process of transforming ideas into reality and ensures their proper implementation. An avid bug hunter, optimizer and standards-lover, Dan likes to push his limits hard.

He has a long history of experiments with various technologies and a love-hate-turned-love relationship with Drupal. You can find him dabbling in Django and Wagtail projects, mapping and translations. 

Aside from computers, his passions include, but are not limited to: coffee, Lego, science fiction and knowledge sharing.

fields.intro: Nick joined Torchbox in summer 2013 in a career-changing move from the secondary-school classroom
fields.biography:
Nick graduated from Oxford University with a degree in Mathematics and Philosophy, and since then has managed to move an exotic 11 miles down the road to Witney.

He has a pilot's license, but his commercial flying career was doomed from the start when his interview invitation for BA's pilot training programme arrived on 11 September 2001. Instead he trained as a maths teacher and spent ten years working in Oxfordshire's comprehensive schools. Eventually teaching himself to code in order to make a pupil-tracking web application, Nick suddenly realised that he was enjoying this more than the day job, and so packed up his bags to head over to Torchbox.

He has previous lives as a moderately quick track cyclist, a moderately competitive photographer and a moderately decent trombone player. Now he is a moderately competent husband and father of two.

Anagrams of his name include Nicholas Smith, NicholaS smith and tmcaNisl hohSi.

fields.intro: Tom is a developer from Oxford.
fields.biography: Tom has a BSc in biology, but he liked computers better so he got an MSc in them instead. He joined Torchbox as a Python Developer in 2014 after doing a bit of Java development. He likes free software, hard sci-fi and the countryside.

fields.intro: After gaining a D.Phil in Astrophysics from St. John's College, Oxford, Helen spent several years as an academic researcher in theoretical and observational cosmology, gaining an international reputation.
fields.biography:
Since joining Torchbox at its inception, Helen's work as a Senior Developer has marshalled important projects from concept and specifications through technical build and UAT to training and launch. Projects she's worked on recently include a monitoring, evaluation and project management tool for the Football Foundation, and a case management system from Pohwer, the advocacy service. 

Helen's skills lie in technical programming, database design, code optimisation, and working with clients to turn their requirements into technical specifications. She also has a keen interest in quality control. Outside work Helen has a strong interest in sustainable living and community building.

fields.intro: Karl joined Torchbox in October 2013
Ru likes making websites, always with open source software, and usually with Drupal.
fields.biography:
Born in San Francisco when his parents lived there for a while, Ru was bought back to the UK just quick enough not to remember any of the fantastic scenery or weather. He settled in the west country, via Hampshire and Reading, gaining a degree in Computer Science from the University of Bath along the way. He now lives in Bristol with his girlfriend, their daughter and a dog. Minnie the whippet can often be found creating her own brand of chaos in the Torchbox Bristol office.

When he's not doing things with computers, Ru likes riding bikes, taking pictures of things, taking things apart to see what's in them, drinking bourbon and combinations of these activities.

fields.intro: At Torchbox since Oct 2011.
fields.biography:
Pete has more Twitter followers than the rest of Torchbox combined.

Half Marathon Personal Best: Around 2 hour 17. He was barely conscious during the last 15 minutes.

Talk to him about Facebook management, Twitter campaigns and how to get the most out your social media data.

fields.intro: Coming to Torchbox after almost a decade working on design, development and communications in the third-sector, Tom is an experienced digital all-rounder.
fields.biography: Tom can also be found shutting down his Macbook and heading for the hills. Cycling, river swimming, drinking whiskey in the evenings and black coffee in the mornings.

fields.intro: Kate joined Torchbox in September of 2014. A keen OSS advocate, she has worked in SysAdmin roles for a number of years.
fields.biography:
Kate graduated from Aberystwyth University in 2010 with a degree in Computer Science. Aber Uni has strong links with the Open Source community leading to her becoming a volunteer at the international conference FOSDEM in Brussels. She came to Torchbox after spending some time traveling Down Under.

In her spare time Kate goes to the gym, climbs, and learns Shorinji Kempo. That being said, you're most likely to find her behind a book, baking or engaging in far more geeky activities.

fields.intro: Senior Developer at Torchbox since 2001, a grey-haired member of the 'Torchbox Tenner Club'
fields.biography: Specialises in designing and building large, bespoke web applications and providing users with intuitive interfaces to complex systems.

fields.intro: Ged joined Torchbox in January 2013 with a background in digital campaigning and project management.
fields.biography:
He began his career in academic publishing but 'went digital' when he moved to the University of Oxford and project managed the development and delivery of nearly 40 graduate and postgraduate online courses. Joining Oxfam GB in 2008, Ged cared for the Oxfam Education website and then spent 4 years managing Oxfam's digital campaigning in the UK. Before all that he studied English Literature as a graduate and Publishing as a postgraduate.

Ged's ideal day starts with a hearty breakfast and ends on the dancefloor; taking in a thick novel, a few hours of televised sport and an afternoon on the cricket pitch. Having DJ'd in and around Oxford for years, sunrise with friends has become his favourite thing to look forward to.

fields.intro: Ellen joined Torchbox in 2014 with a background in publishing.
fields.biography:
After graduating from the University of Bristol with a degree in English and Classics, Ellen started out in educational publishing, before moving into the arena of research dissemination. In her previous role she oversaw websites, print magazines and digital publications for a whole host of interesting European research projects. Since joining Torchbox, she has worked with CLIC Sargent, Nuffield Trust and WRAP, among others. 

In her spare time she is a passionate reader and consumer of TV series. She currently studies a part-time course in Theology, helps run a youth group and this year completed the Bristol Half Marathon for the first time.

fields.intro: Paul joined Torchbox in July 2014, moving from King's College London's internationally renowned Department of Digital Humanities.  And that's where he met Wagtail.  It was love at first site.
fields.biography:
As Senior Account Director, Paul looks to develop solid insight into clients' digital needs and strategic goals with a view to making sure that we apply our technical chops to deliver the smartest, most efficient and most sustainable solutions we can.  He also keeps an eye on things to ensure that we deliver a consistently high level of service.  

At KCL, Paul headed up a large R&D team designing and building complex custom web applications.  As well as a deep understanding of the Higher Education sector, Paul brings extensive experience working as a consultant to, and collaborator with, many arts and cultural heritage organisations including Tate, the South Bank Centre and the Royal Opera House.  He also ran his own digital agency for over ten years.

When not working, Paul has been known to play the harp.  Moreover he likes to pretend he is Simon Hopkinson in the kitchen, and gets grumpy if unable to swim at least 12.5km a week.

fields.intro: Rob is our social media crusader who loves overseeing engagement across our client communities.
fields.biography:
Rob joined Torchbox in December 2013. From a digital project management background, he effortlessly made the transition into the Digital Marketing Team, culminating in an individual able to deliver on-time and budget and reach out to engage new audiences.

Predominantly covering the social management for our Sports clients, he loves being creative and enjoys coming up with experimental ideas and putting them to the test. Specialising in compelling creative content, Rob also manages the Torchbox Blog.

Rob keeps abreast of the latest online marketing news and trends, but on a personal note: is a converted cat-lover, die-hard football fan, and his favourite Pokémon is Scyther (the bug/flying type - terrible combo).

fields.intro: Leon joined Torchbox in September 2014.
fields.biography:
After a Masters degree in Publishing at Oxford Brookes, Leon moved to London and started working in educational publishing, first at HarperCollins and then at Discovery. He worked on a range of digital products, from whiteboard software to smartphone apps, and also spent some time freelancing as a motion graphics designer and Wordpress developer. Five years later, he couldn't handle the distance from Oxford anymore and moved back.

Leon is originally from Sweden and lived in Stockholm, Perugia and Venice before coming to the UK.

In his spare time, he indulges in creative writing and podcasts about Doctor Who.

fields.intro: Phil joined Torchbox in 2014. He works with clients to ensure they're getting the best out of their Google Ad Grants accounts.
fields.biography:
He is Google AdWords & Analytics certified and manages multiple Google Ad Grants for our charity clients. Prior to Torchbox, he studied English Literature at Oxford Brookes University, graduating in 2005. He signed a five-album record deal with Sony BMG during this period, supported Girls Aloud in front of 25,000 people, reached the summit when his band was bigged up by Jonathan Ross and Noddy Holder on BBC Radio 2 and worked with producers and engineers all over the UK. 

His favourite poet is Norman MacCaig, and his pen pal is the writer Graham Swift.

fields.intro: At Torchbox since Oct 2011.
fields.biography:
Pete has more Twitter followers than the rest of Torchbox combined.

Half Marathon Personal Best: Around 1 hour 40. He was barely conscious during the last 15 minutes.

Talk to him about Facebook management, Twitter campaigns and how to get the most out your social media data.

fields.intro: Rob is our social media crusader who loves overseeing engagement across our client communities.
fields.biography:
Rob joined Torchbox in December 2013. From a digital project management background, he effortlessly made the transition into the Digital Marketing Team, culminating in an individual able to deliver on-time and budget and reach out to engage new audiences.

Predominantly covering the social management for our Sports clients, he loves being creative and enjoys coming up with experimental ideas and putting them to the test. 

Rob keeps abreast of the latest online marketing news and trends, but on a personal note: is a converted cat-lover, die-hard football fan, and his favourite Pokémon is Scyther (the bug/flying type - terrible combo).

fields.intro: Susan is our Financial Manager and has been with Torchbox on and off since 2001.
fields.biography: As well as looking after our invoicing, accounts and payroll and all that other essential stuff, Susan also makes sure we all have comfortable chairs and that the coffee, biscuits and fruit never run out. Susan is also a director of a logistics company with her husband. She loves walking and running, and is a former ultra long distance runner who once ran all the way from London to Brighton. She also enjoys sewing and gardening.

fields.intro: Dave has been working for Torchbox since 2007.
fields.biography:
He has managed digital projects for The King's Fund, Greenpeace, ActionAid, International Committee of the Red Cross, WRAP, WWF, the RSA and more.

After four years as a Project Manager in our Oxfordshire HQ, Dave spent six months travelling and two years as Digital Manager at the UK's leading cycling and walking charity, Sustrans. 

He rejoined Torchbox in 2014 as Account Director. He loves to get close to our clients' objectives, developing strategies, and making sure that we're working together on projects that will have measurable impact.

Outside work he's a proud dad, keen cyclist, part-time runner, infrequent wild-swimmer, and beginner swing dancer.

fields.intro: Jonny joined Torchbox in April 2010 after previous experience in the digital marketing world of alcohol at Molson Coors.
fields.biography:
Swapping free crates of beer and a heightened sense of popularity, Jonny moved to Oxford on the promise of beautiful countryside, barbecues and ski slopes. So far so good. 

Joining a fledgling marketing team at the time, Jonny has worked across a range of disciplines - gaining experience in all areas of digital marketing.  He currently specialises in social media campaigns, strategy & advertising.  

Among his recent achievements, he lists helping to organise the first branded live Facebook Q&A in the UK, meeting Mr Motivator and getting David Hasselhoff to Tweet about Torchbox’s work.

Outside of work he’s a huge sport fan, social media junkie and has a habit of signing up to challenges that require death waivers.

fields.intro: Matthew is the lead technical developer of the Wagtail CMS, and works on custom web application development, both server-side and front-end.
fields.biography:
Matthew joined Torchbox straight out of uni in 2002 and immediately got involved in the development of Torchbox's original CMS, RationalMedia. Along the way he's gained extensive experience with the workings of content-managed websites, and most recently has headed the development of the open-source Wagtail CMS that powers many of Torchbox's latest sites.

He also has a keen interest in browser-side technologies, and has been exploring the possibilities of Javascript since before Google Maps and jQuery made it cool, creating rich data visualisations and mapping applications for the likes of WWF and ActionAid.

Outside of Torchbox, Matthew is actively involved in the demoscene - an international community of programmers and artists creating digital artworks - and regularly visits festivals across Europe presenting new code creations and live music performances. He is also currently on a long term mission to hike all of the UK's National Trails.

fields.intro: Jonny joined Torchbox in April 2010 after previous experience in the digital marketing world of alcohol at Molson Coors.
fields.biography:
Swapping free crates of beer and a heightened sense of popularity, Jonny moved to Oxford on the promise of beautiful countryside, barbecues and ski slopes. So far so good. 

Joining a fledgling marketing team at the time, Jonny has worked across a range of disciplines - gaining experience in all areas of digital marketing.  He currently specialises in social media campaigns, strategy & advertising.  

Among his recent achievements, he lists helping to organise the first branded live Facebook Q&A in the UK, meeting Mr Motivator and getting David Hasselhoff to Tweet about Torchbox’s work.

Outside of work he’s a huge sport fan, social media junkie and has a habit of signing up to challenges that require death waivers.

fields.intro: Rob is our digital marketing specialist who loves it when a plan comes together.
fields.biography: Rob loves to wax lyrical about the merits of creating compelling content and making that content famous. This is what he aimed for with the award-winning Carling programme that he led at Molson Coors where he worked on 'iPint' - one of the UK's most popular iPhone apps. Rob loves to work up a good plan and then go on about 'making it happen'. He sits on the IAB's Social Media Council and is a former Chair of ISBA's Digital Action Group. If you fancy a curry, a pint, a good natter about football and a sing song, then head to Rob's house!

fields.intro: James came to Torchbox as a recent graduate from UWE (BA(Hons) Graphic Design).
fields.biography: He has a love for simplistic and beautiful design with an acute attention to typographic detail. When he's not kerning type or creating colour palettes he can be found sampling beers from Bristol's finest public houses. James is a merit awarded member of The International Society of Typographic Designers.

fields.intro: Felicity joined Torchbox in 2012 with a background in large-scale Unix web hosting.
fields.biography:
After dropping out of high school at 17, Felicity joined the Wikimedia developer team in 2004, with a background in Unix but little experience of the real world.  She picked up her experience with scaling web sites 'on the fly', as Wikipedia grew from 7 servers to over 200 on a ridiculously small budget.

She joined Torchbox in 2012, where she's spent most of her time overhauling our hosting infrastructure, while fielding clients' technical questions, dealing with the typical unexpected problems that plague computers, and crawling under desks to fix the office wiring.

When not working, Felicity spends her time playing fiddle or sampling the latest beers at Charlbury's pubs (sometimes at the same time).

fields.intro: Victoria moved from sweaty Singapore to the UK in 2004 to join Torchbox. She wears her coat in the office on most days.
Jason joined Torchbox in 2015 after taking over a year out to go on a bunch of adventures.
fields.biography:
This included cycling in Europe, motorbiking in SE Asia, skiing in France and road tripping in USA. He decided it was time to come home, when he started believing “Into the Wild” was the ultimate travel experience.

Before becoming a nomad he worked for Motivation Charitable Trust in Bristol & Nairobi and is still involved in international development & advocacy through RESULTS.

fields.intro: After flexing his ops muscles at a previous digital agency, Paul joined Torchbox in March 2015.
fields.biography:
14 years of event management experience gave Paul the ability to see the big picture, and then zero in on the tiniest detail, providing the perfect foundation for the world of operations. 

Paul keeps a beady eye on all current and future resources, making sure we are able to deliver our client projects with utmost efficiency.

Outside of work, Paul likes to punish his body with things like squash and the occasional Tough Mudder event, as well as being Chief Entertainer to his two young daughters and trying to keep his garden in some sort of order.

fields.intro: Maya joined Torchbox in early 2015.
fields.biography:
After graduating from Glasgow University with a BSc Hons in Software Engineering, Maya's intended year of travel turned into a more prolonged stint of working abroad, spending time working on the coral reefs of Western Australia and in the mountains of the French Alps. 5 years on it was time to return to the UK, joining another digital agency in Bristol as a Project Manager.

Maya's previous role saw her managing projects for various charities, non-for-profits and NGOs so the progression to Torchbox was obvious. Since joining Torchbox she has been working with Oxford University, The Future Leaders Trust as well as some exciting new projects!

In her spare time Maya pursues the activities of her time abroad, enjoying hill walking, diving (in the slightly colder waters of the UK!) and planning the next skiing adventure.

fields.intro: Former contractor, Toby has found somewhere that implements the values he finds most important to him.
fields.biography:
Since graduating in 2004 from University of Westminster, he has been building UI's for a range of designers and agencies looking to do something different on the internet and within native applications. Tying this into best practice development, adhering to standards and keeping an ear out for new techniques is what makes him happy when delivering projects.

During his career so far he has worked with some of the most passionate developers around the world at agencies such as AKQA and IRIS Digital, has evangelised best practice at Nokia in Berlin, and setup a beautiful co-op workspace in Wales.

Outside of work Toby enjoys annoying artisans with beginner questions, socialising, befriending cats, snow, Radio 4 and finding new electronic music.

fields.intro: Andy joined Torchbox in 2015 with a background in Paid Search.
fields.biography:
He has attained Google Adwords Certification, and currently manages several Google Ad Grant Pro accounts for our Charity clients. 

Working with Google Adwords has given him an irrational hatred of the numbers 26 and 36 and a good knowledge of synonyms that are two characters smaller than the original word.
